column5: The sexual basis of racial formation: Anti-vice activism and the creation of the twentieth-century 'color line'. [References].
column10: Donovan, Brian: Department of Sociology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, US
column11: Ethnic and Racial Studies. Vol.26(4), Jul 2003, pp. 707-727.
column18: White slavery narratives--stories about white women forced into prostitution--played an important role in the construction of racial distinctions in the early twentieth century. New York City politicians launched a well-publicized anti-vice crusade in 1910 that led to the imprisonment of a mixed-race woman named Belle Moore. In this article, I analyse this event to show the importance of sexuality and gender for creating racial boundaries. Testimony in People vs. Belle Moore designated certain intimacies as violating the color line, thereby clarifying what it meant to be 'White' or 'Colored'. I argue that theories of racial formation must include a more careful consideration of gender and sexuality because the ongoing maintenance of racial categories depends upon cultural narratives about sexual deviance and purity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Reporting behavior of military sexual coercion and sexual assault victims.
column10: Ramming, Marilyn Kay: U Northern Colorado, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(11-B), May 2003, pp. 5503.
column18: This study investigated sexual assault in the military and situations in which it is and is not reported to authorities. Data from the Department of Defense 1995 Sexual Harassment Survey were used to conduct logistic regression analyses. The sample for this study consisted of 310 female respondents who indicated experiencing sexual coercion and 248 female respondents who indicated experiencing sexual assault. It was hypothesized that military victims of sexual coercion and assault would be less likely to report to authorities if the perpetrator held higher rank than the victim. It was also hypothesized that military victims of sexual coercion and assault would be more likely to report if they considered the situation to be sexual harassment. Neither of these factors had a statistically significant influence on reporting behavior. The following factors significantly influenced the probability of reporting by sexual coercion victims: race/ethnicity of African American and a situation of sexual coercion lasting from one to six months lowered the probability of reporting; multiple perpetrators of mixed race/ethnicity (some the same as the victim, some different) and the victim feeling "very" or "extremely" disturbed or threatened by the situation increased the probability of reporting. The following factors significantly influenced the probability of a sexual assault victim reporting: race/ethnicity of African American or Hispanic/other, a situation with one perpetrator compared to situations with multiple perpetrators, and situations lasting one to six months lowered the probability of reporting; being a member of the Army, Navy, or Coast Guard, age in twenties or thirties, and situations in which the victim felt "very" or "extremely" threatened increased the probability of reporting. Future research that distinguishes between forms of sexual harassment is needed in order to identify and understand barriers to reporting. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: White, Black, and multiracial perceptions of interracial interactions.
column10: Branigan Villanueva, Christine Akissi: U Michigan, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(7-B), Jan 2003, pp. 3512.
column18: Three studies investigated white, black, and multiracial individuals' perceptions of interracial interactions. In Study 1, participants viewed a brief animated film depicting a group converging on an individual. In Study 2 the film depicted an individual leaving a group. The racial composition of the interactions varied. Results from these two studies suggest that participants believe that whites have a fear and dislike of blacks, that blacks are more individualistic than whites, that multiracials have more fluid racial boundaries for classifying mixed-raced individuals than whites and blacks, and that mixed-race people are better adjusted than whites and blacks think they are. In study 3 respondents viewed a film depicting an individual leaving its partner for a different individual. Results of Study 3 suggest that blacks and multiracials are more capable of dealing with rejection situations than whites, perhaps because whites are not used to attributing negative events to external causes (e.g., racial discrimination). Together, the three studies explored people's culturally shared beliefs concerning racial group membership and race relations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Breaking barriers for multiracial individuals and families. [References].
column11: Harper, Frederick D [Ed]; McFadden, John [Ed]. (2003). Culture and counseling: New approaches.  (pp. 313-323). xxi, 426 pp. Needham Heights, MA, US: Allyn & Bacon; US.
column18: (from the chapter) In this brief chapter, the author hopes to achieve two goals: (1) to introduce readers to issues, challenges, and barriers faced by multiracial individuals and interracial families in the United States and (2) to suggest counseling strategies for helping people in the mixed-race population to overcome these barriers. The history of race mixing in the United States is addressed in Wehrly (1996) and Wehrly, Kenney, and Kenney (1999) and will not be repeated here. After a section on definitions of terms pertinent to the interracial population, this chapter will concentrate on societal and professional issues related to work with the mixed-race population and on counseling strategies to assist mixed-race individuals and families in breaking barriers that may be inhibiting the attainment of their full human potential. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Stories of race and sex in the Andes.
column10: Paulson, Susan: Miami U, Oxford, OH, US
column11: Sexualities. Vol.6(3-4), Nov 2003, pp. 497-500.
column18: In this provocative book Mary Weismantel explores experiences, practices and social structures of race and sex in the Andes through stories generated around two contradictory characters, cultural icons that thrive on tensions between fantasy and reality. Images of mixed race cholas arouse in white men both desire and disgust for women who difference makes them exciting and whose racial and sexual subordination makes them available. Stories of horrifying white bogeymen called pishtacos frighten poor Indians and women, and evoke their own vulnerability to the predations of the powerful. Weismantel argues that the cultural icons of the sensual brown woman called chola and the aggressively penetrating white man known as pishtaco are not innocent fantasies, for they arouse the violent passions of societies fractured by race and sex, and divided by vast economic inequalities. In a book that is not about gays or lesbians per se, Weismantel helps to queer Andean studies by questioning heteronormative assumptions that often frame discussions of rape, body and identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Health and Behavior Risks of Adolescents with Mixed-Race Identity. [References].
column9:

Li, Rose Maria

column10:
Udry, J. Richard: Carolina Population Center, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, US
Li, Rose Maria: Analytical Sciences, Inc., US
Hendrickson-Smith, Janet: Carolina Population Center, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, US
column11: American Journal of Public Health. Vol.93(11), Nov 2003, pp. 1865-1870.
column18: Objectives. This study compared the health and risk status of adolescents who identify with 1 race with those identifying with more than 1 race. Methods. Data are derived from self-reports of race, using the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health (Add Health), which provides a large representative national sample of adolescents in grades 7 through 12. Respondents could report more than 1 race. Results. Mixed-race adolescents showed higher risk when compared with single-race adolescents on general health questions, school experience, smoking and drinking, and other risk variables. Conclusions. Adolescents who self-identify as more than 1 race are at higher health and behavior risks. The findings are compatible with interpreting the elevated risk of mixed race as associated with stress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Critical race theory and white racism: Is there room for white scholars in fighting racism in education? [References].
column10: Bergerson, Amy Aldous: University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, US
column11: International Journal of Qualitative Studies in Education. Vol.16(1), Jan-Feb 2003, pp. 51-63.
column18: Critical race theory (CRT) offers educational researchers a compelling way to view racism in education by centering issues of race and using counterstories to challenge dominant views in both research and practice. This article provides an overview of CRT and illuminates the dilemmas for white researchers wishing to incorporate CRT into their work. The author argues that while CRT may not be fully open to white researchers, their strategic use of CRT can help legitimize its use in fighting racism in educational settings. Building on her participation in CRT discussions in a mixed-race setting, the author suggests that white researchers must work to center race in their personal lives and work, engage in the strategic and sensitive use of CRT, and join in the effort to legitimize research that utilizes alternative methods such as CRT. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multiple realities: A relational narrative approach in therapy with Black-White mixed-race clients. [References].
column9:
Rockquemore, Kerry Ann

Laszloffy, Tracey A
column11: Family Relations: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Applied Family Studies. Vol.52(2), Apr 2003, pp. 119-128.
column18: Notions of a racial identity for persons with one Black and one White parent have assumed the existence of only a singular identity (first Black and later biracial). Emerging empirical research on racial identity formation among members of this group reveals that multiple identity options are possible. In terms of overall health, the level of social invalidation one encounters with respect to racial self-identification is more important than the specific racial identity selected. Here a relational narrative approach to therapy with Black-White mixed-race clients who experience systematic invalidation of their chosen racial identity is presented through a detailed case illustration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Cigarette smoking for weight loss or control among adolescents: Gender and racial/ethnic differences. [References].
column9:
Fulkerson, Jayne A

French, Simone A
column10:
Fulkerson, Jayne A.: U Minnesota, Dept of Epidemiology, Minneapolis, MN, US
French, Simone A.: U Minnesota, Dept of Epidemiology, Minneapolis, MN, US
column11: Journal of Adolescent Health. Vol.32(4), Apr 2003, pp. 306-313.
column18: Describes gender and racial/ethnic differences in the prevalence of cigarette smoking for weight loss or control in an adolescent population-based sample, and relationships among heavy smoking, weight concerns and smoking to lose or control weight. Anonymous questionnaires were administered to 81,247 9th and 12th grade public school students. Variables of interest included smoking frequency, weight concerns, and smoking for weight loss or control. With the exception of black females, female smokers of different racial/ethnic groups were as likely as white girls to smoke for weight loss or control. Compared to white male smokers, American Indian and Asian American male smokers were more likely to smoke for weight loss or control, and black, Hispanic, and mixed race male smokers were equally likely to smoke for weight loss or control. Heavy smokers, smokers who perceived themselves as overweight or were weight-concerned were significantly more likely to report smoking as a weight control method. Smoking for weight control is prevalent across many race/ethinic groups and both genders among adolescents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial identity, the Apartheid state, and the limits of political mobilization and democratic reform in South Africa: The case of the University of the Western Cape. [References].
column10: Anderson, Gregory M.: Columbia University, Teachers College, New York, NY, US
column11: Identity: An International Journal of Theory and Research. Vol.3(1), 2003, pp. 29-52.
column18: In this article I examine how a so-called "bush" college designated under Apartheid for the education of Coloured (mixed-race) students contributed to the radicalization of South Africa's Western Cape region. The creation of the University of the Western Cape (UWC) was part of an Apartheid divide and rule strategy to inhibit the development of political alliances between mixed-race and indigenous African peoples. However, in 1982, UWC rejected the use of Apartheid classifications for selecting entrants, thereby establishing the country's first non-racial, open admissions policy. UWC paid a price for its principled efforts, as the Apartheid regime slashed state subsidies and engaged the institution in a protracted legal and ideological struggle over the right to determine its own educational policies. Viewing UWC's transformation as microcosm of the country's negotiated settlement to end Apartheid, the article concludes with a critical discussion of Coloured identity and the limits of democratic reform in post-Apartheid South Africa. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: The conceptualisation and categorisation of mixed race/ethnicity in Britain and North America: Identity options and the role of the state. [References].
column10: Aspinall, P. J.: Centre for Health Services Studies, George Allen Wing University of Kent at Canterbury, Canterbury, England
column11: International Journal of Intercultural Relations. Vol.27(3), May 2003, pp. 269-296.
column18: Estimates of around 1.7-2.4% of the population in the USA, 2% in Canada, and 0.6% in Britain now self-identify as mixed race. Inter-ethnic unions comprise around 2.7% of all unions in the USA and 1.3% in Britain and are increasing. The impact of these changes on the ethnic/racial diversity of Britain and North America and the demand from persons of mixed race to describe their 'full' identity requires a response from government and Census agencies that classify the population by race/ethnicity. Research show that the self-understandings of persons of mixed race may incorporate a range of identities, some biracial and others a single group like 'black', although the options available in the USA may still be limited by the legacy of the hypodescent policy. The solutions offered by classifications in the 2000/2001 round of censuses include a subdivided 'mixed' category in England and Wales and provision to select one or more categories in the USA. This marks an end to the official conceptualisation of 'pure' races that has been so pervasive in the past and, for the first time, offers mixed race identity to those of mixed heritage. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: The formation of in-group favoritism and out-group prejudice in young children: Are they distinct attitudes? [References].
column10: Aboud, Frances E.: McGill U, Montreal, PQ, Canada
column11: Developmental Psychology. Vol.39(1), Jan 2003, pp. 48-60.
column18: Although standardized measures of prejudice reveal high levels of ethnocentric bias in the preschool years, it may reflect in-group favoritism or out-group prejudice. A measure that partially decouples the two attitudes was given to White children between 4 and 7 years of age to examine the reciprocal relation between and the acquisition and correlates of in-group and out-group attitudes. The two attitudes were reciprocally correlated in 1 sample from a racially homogeneous school but not in a 2nd sample from a mixed-race school. In-group favoritism did not appear until 5 years of age but then reached significant levels; it was strongly related to developing social cognitions. Out-group prejudice was weaker, but its targets suffer from comparison with the high favoritism accorded in-group members. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Biracial, bicultural, bisexual: Bisexuality and multiple identities. [References].
column10: Dworkin, Sari H.: California State U, Fresno, CA, US
column11: Journal of Bisexuality. Vol.2(4), 2002, pp. 93-107.
column18: This article is based on interviews of twenty-seven women (aged 20-59 yrs). The women were primarily Caucasian, but a few were of mixed race. This article focuses on the women of mixed race and one or more Caucasian women who met other cultural aspects of identity such as religious beliefs, age, and politics. The purpose is to discuss how these factors impact their construction of bisexual identity. First comes a brief review of the literature on sexual identity models, racial identity models, age differences, religious differences, and feminism. Then the women speak. Following each woman's voice, her main points are related to therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: IQ, birth weight, and number of sexual partners in White, African American, and mixed race adolescents. [References].
column10: Rowe, David C.: U Arizona, Tucson, AZ, US
column11: Population and Environment: A Journal of Interdisciplinary Studies. Vol.23(6), Jul 2002, pp. 513-524.
column18: Compared verbal IQ, number of sexual partners, and birth weight among African-American, White-American, and Black/White mixed race US adolescents. 4,271 African-American, 10,315 White-American, and 116 Black/White mixed race US adolescents (mean age 16 yrs) completed questionnaires and tests concerning verbal IQ, number of sexual partners, birth weight, parental education, and family income. Results show that African-American subjects(Ss) reported lower birth weight, lower verbal IQ, and higher number of sexual partners than did White Ss. For each characteristic, the mean of mixed-race Ss fell between the means of the 2 other populations. Birth weights were heavier as social class increased. In African-American Ss, the number of sexual partners was not associated with social class; those associations were weak in White Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: (from the introduction) This reprinted article originally appeared in Counselling, Journal of the British Association for Counselling, 1997, 8(4), 282-284. The author focuses on how to work with issues of race in counseling. She refers to relevant models to help counselors access the different development stages that the counselor and client may have attained that aid understanding of the dynamics which may emerge during counseling. column5: The case of Carla: Dilemmas of helping all students to understand science. [References].
column9:
Kurth, Lori A

Anderson, Charles W

Palincsar, Annemarie S
column10:
Kurth, Lori A.: American Association for the Advancement of Science, Project 2061, Washington, DC, US
Anderson, Charles W.: Michigan State U, Coll of Education, Dept of Teacher Education, East Lansing, MI, US
Palincsar, Annemarie S.: U Michigan, School of Education, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column11: Science Education. Vol.86(3), May 2002, pp. 287-313.
column18: This paper tells the story of 4 sixth-grade students, of mixed race and social class, who worked together in a small group and experimented with colored solutions of different densities. In spite of common interests, they often failed to achieve intersubjective communication about the colored solutions or about the process of planning and making a poster to report their findings. The authors explain this using the concepts of polysemy, privileging, and holding the floor. In particular, Carla (an African American girl) was unable to hold the floor within the group, so her opportunities for science learning were diminished. The four students were not overtly prejudiced in their speech or actions. Yet the expectations they brought with them led them to reconstruct among themselves some of the most troubling inequities of our society as a whole. This story is about important connections. In particular it is about how the actions of children are connected to the histories of their families, and how the privileging of ideas is connected to that of people, and how the practice of science is connected to that of discrimination. Science education reformers may underestimate the difficulty of separating conceptual conflict about ideas from interpersonal conflict about privilege and status. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interrogating the hyphen-nation: Canadian multicultural policy and 'mixed-race' identities. [References].
column10: Mahtani, Minelle: U of British Columbia, Sing Tao School of Journalism, Dept of Geography, Vancouver, BC, Canada
column11: Social Identities: Journal for the Study of Race, Nation and Culture. Vol.8(1), Mar 2002, pp. 67-90.
column18: This paper examines the ways 'mixed race' women in Canada contemplate their relationship to national identity. Through qualitative, open-ended interviews with 24 women identified as 'mixed race' (aged 20-55 yrs), the research demonstrates how some women of 'mixed race' contest ideas of the nation as constituted through the policy of multiculturalism in Canada. To challenge the tropes of the national narrative, some women of 'mixed race' develop nuanced models of cultural citizenship, illustrating that national identities are formed and transformed in relation to representation. Refusing to be positioned outside the nation, they effectively produce their own meanings of identity by working through their own personally identified 'mixed race' bodies to the national body politic, where some of them see their own bodies as intrinsically 'multicultural'. The paper ends by addressing the paradoxes of multiculturalism, emphasising through narratives that the policy produces hierarchical spaces against which some 'mixed race' women imaginatively negotiate, contest and challenge perceptions of their racialised and gendered selves. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Considering the significance of ancestry through the prism of mixed-race identity. [References].

column11: Advances in Nursing Science. Vol.25(2), Dec 2002, pp. 1-21.
column18: Examined the significance of ancestry on racial identity and its influence on healthcare. 20 individuals of mixed African-American-White and Asian-American-White ancestries (aged 45-94 yrs) completed interviews concerning self-identity. Results show that racial identity included the 5 dimensions of cultural identity, ascribed racial identity, racial identification to others, racial self-identification, and situational racialization of feeling. Mixed African-Americans described greater consistency in ascribed racial identity and a consistency between ascribed racial identity and racial identification to others. Mixed Asian-American subjects appeared to be less restricted by racial definitions. Findings suggest that the assessment of health care needs should not be based on narrow definitions of race. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Jensen effects and African/Coloured/Indian/White differences on Raven's Standard Progressive Matrices in South Africa. [References].
column10: Rushton, J. Philippe: U Western Ontario, Dept of Psychology, London, ON, Canada
column11: Personality and Individual Differences. Vol.33(8), Dec 2002, pp. 1279-1284.
column18: A test is made to determine whether various ethnic group differences on tests of cognitive performance in South Africa are like the Black/White differences in the US in being positively associated with a tests' g loadings, where g is the general factor of intelligence. A non-parametric re-analysis is made of data from 1,056 White, 1,063 Indian, 778 mixed-race "Coloured," and 1,093 Black 14-yr-olds on the Raven's Standard Progressive Matrices Test in South Africa, given without time limits by K. Owen (1992). The new analyses showed that the more highly correlated an item was with g, the more it predicted the White/Indian/Coloured/African differences on the test (Spearman's rhos from 0.35 to 0.85; all Ps< 0.01). The effects remained regardless of which group g was extracted from. Understanding group differences around the world requires new research on the nature and nurture of g. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: International Journal of Neuroscience. Vol.111(1-2), 2001, pp. 123-132.
column18: Derived indices on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used to screen for cognitive impairments, were examined in a sample of substance abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study (DATOS). The DATOS was a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991 through 1993 within 96 programs in 11 cities in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of substance abusers. The variables of sex, age, ethnicity, and education were statistically significant for selected derived indices of the TMT. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Perception. Vol.30(5), 2001, pp. 611-625.
column18: Examined whether facial averageness and symmetry are attractive in non-Western cultures. Increasing the averageness of individual faces, by warping those faces towards an averaged composite of the same race and sex, increased the attractiveness of both Chinese (Exp 1) and Japanese (Exp 2) faces, for Chinese and Japanese participants, respectively. Decreasing averageness by moving the faces away from an average shape decreased attractiveness. The authors also manipulated the symmetry of Japanese faces by blending each original face with its mirror image to create perfectly symmetric versions. Japanese raters preferred the perfectly symmetric versions to the original faces (Exp 2). These findings show that preferences for facial averageness and symmetry are not restricted to Western cultures, consistent with the view that they are biologically based. Interestingly, it made little difference whether averageness was manipulated by using own-race or other-race averaged composites and there was no preference for own-race averaged composites over other-race or mixed-race composites (Exp 1). We discuss the implications of these results for understanding what makes average faces attractive. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A survey of medical and nursing services to educational centres for children with disabilities in greater Cape Town.
column10: Westwood, A. T. R.: Red Cross War Memorial Children's Hosp, Dept of Paediatrics & Child Health, Rondebosch, South Africa

column13: South African Association for Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and Allied Professions; South Africa
column18: A standard questionnaire was administered to 33 personnel members (nurses or principles) of educational centers for physically and intellectually disabled children under 18 yrs of age. These educational centers included special schools for physically disabled children with normal or borderline IQs, training centers for children with IQ 30-50, and special care centers for profoundly retarded children. The results show that 75% of Black, 40% of mixed race, and 10% of White children had no regular contact with a doctor through their special educational centers. Staff at the centers identified this as a major encumbrance; many times their advice was not followed or no response was received from the referral center. It is concluded that without a coordinated comprehensive system of review for disabled children, it is likely that many problems, including behavioral and psychiatric disorders, are not being adequately dealt with. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Sociological Perspectives. Vol.32(1), Spr 1989, pp. 65-85.
column18: This study provides a demographic portrait of multiracial households, using children as the units of analysis. The authors conceptualize three dimensions for understanding multiracialness: (1) the racial composition of a household overall, (2) where in the household a racial difference exists relative to the household head, and (3) where in the household a racial difference exists relative to each child. Using microdata from the 1980 U.S. census, the authors explore the first two of these dimensions and test two propositions about the links between racial diversity and other nonracial attributes of children's household environments. The finding is made, among other things, that the largest proportion of children live in Asian-white households, and that about 60% live in households headed by mixed-race couples. Support for the notion that attributes of multiracial households fall between those of their same-race counterparts was mixed. Nonetheless, there appears to be a link between location of diversity and some nonracial characteristics of the household. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Cross-racial identification of transformed, untransformed, and mixed-race faces.
column10: Ayuk, Robinson E.: U Wales, School of Psychology, Cardiff, Wales
column11: International Journal of Psychology. Vol.25(4), Aug 1990, pp. 509-527.
column18: Replicated and extended a study by H. D. Ellis and J. B. Deregowski (see record 1982-02697-001) by examining the recognition memory of 32 European and 32 African Ss (aged 18-44 yrs) for same-race, other-race, and mixed-race faces. Faces were either transformed or untransformed in pose between initial study and recognition test. No significant effects on cross-race eyewitness identification were found for either race or either S or target, nor were there any full cross-over interactions. Europeans found transformed faces generally more difficult to identify than Africans. Both races performed well on nontransformed cross-racial faces, but Europeans were significantly poorer on transformed Black faces, indicating an "other-race" effect. Task characteristics may be an important variable in cross-racial identification. (French abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: At the fifth phase of a longitudinal study of transracial adoption outcomes, 52 adolescents of black descent adopted in infancy were examined with respect to racial self-identity, general adjustment, and self-esteem. The 34 adolescents adopted into white families and the 18 adopted into black families identified themselves as black or of mixed race in similar proportions, and most were found to be well adjusted and to have good or very good self-esteem. The findings offer implications for adoption policy and placement decisions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column18: 80 Black and 80 White undergraduate and graduate women (aged 18-41 yrs) were presented with a set of materials depicting 2 women as verbally aggressive. In a between-Ss design, each S was presented with a set of materials depicting one of the following: 2 women who were (1) of the same race as the S, (2) of a different race from the S, or (3) a mixed racial pair. Each S was asked to rate the randomly chosen identified aggressor on several variables related to aggression. Results of a 2 x 2 x 2 multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) involving race of participant, race of identified aggressor, and race of target indicate a main effect of race of Ss such that the White Ss viewed all episodes as more aggressive than the Black Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Investigated the prevalence of the notion of Black children's negative self-concept among 102 postgraduate social work students at 2 British universities, and examined the extent of the influence of this view on professional practice. Ss responded individually to 3 randomly distributed vignettes, which were identical except for the racial/ethnic origin of the principal characters: a White child, a child of mixed-race parentage, and a Black child. Ss were required to assess the causes of the children's behavior, as well as their social and psychological needs. Results were analyzed according to the number of Ss who mentioned particular causes of the children's behavior and particular courses of action to meet their needs. Analyses revealed significant differences between the Ss' perceptions and interpretations of the children's behavior. Children also were differentially treated according to their race or ethnic origin. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Determined prevalence of depressive symptoms in African-American medical clinic patients (aged 50+ yrs) and described the depressive symptoms and depressive illness. 66 African Americans in active treatment at a university hospital medical clinic were screened for the presence of depressive symptoms with the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D). 32% of the Ss screened positive for depressive symptoms. Based on a clinical interview using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-III-Revised (DSM-III-R) checklist, 11% had affective disorders and were referred for psychiatric evaluation. Data demonstrate that levels of depressive symptoms among medically ill, African American medical clinic patients with 2 or more medical illnesses were higher than reported for medical clinic samples composed of White Americans or mixed race Ss. column11: Journal of Clinical Psychology. Vol.51(2), Mar 1995, pp. 294-302.
column18: Examines manifestations of childhood borderline conditions on the Rorschach. The use of the testing interaction and the unique productions on projective techniques, especially the Rorschach, provide remarkable vistas into the primitive agonies, disordered attachments, and chaotic representational worlds of children with borderline personality disorders (BPDs). Their core sense of self has not achieved the sort of stability, constancy, and integrity that allow for effective functioning in the world. Continuity with adult forms of BPDs has been demonstrated in some studies. Poor outcomes and persistent psychopathology are expected for most children who fall within this spectrum of disorders. A case study of a 14-yr-old mixed-race girl is presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Adoption is now seen as a form of child care, one of a spectrum of resources for children in need. Adopted children generally show a good outcome but are overrepresented in clinical populations. This trend is likely to continue as older children with histories of severe deprivation, neglect, abuse, and institutionalization are placed. Attitudes to the adoption of mixed-race and older children are also changing: Black- and mixed-race children are becoming easier to place. Developmental studies have thrown new light on revealing to children that they were adopted. Adoption disruption increases with age and other factors at placement, requiring further research into its origins and management. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Examined differences among 180 Xhosa-speaking Black adolescents, 89 Afrikaans-speaking adolescents of mixed racial descent, 432 English-speaking White, and 117 Afrikaans-speaking White adolescents (aged 13-19 yrs) within a context of social change in South Africa. For comparison purposes, data were also collected from 263 White American adolescents. Ss completed a questionnaire that assessed aspects of these groups' perceptions of themselves (their identities), attitudes toward other racial groups (their prejudices), and beliefs about changes in the socio-political environment in South Africa. Overall, Ss demonstrated generally positive attitudes toward aspects of their own culture and slightly favorable attitudes toward interracial tolerance. They also demonstrated a moderate to positive sense of similarity to other members of their own race. Several statistically significant differences between all the groups were found. Comparative analyses on identity and attitude variables performed with White American adolescents were also statistically significant for all groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Studied the development and psychometric characteristics of the Functional Assessment of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection (FAHI), a quality of life instrument composed of the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT-G) plus a finite set of symptoms and concerns specific to HIV infection. The FACT-G and a 9-item HIV-specific subscale were combined and administered to 18-63 yr olds: 110 English-speaking, stress management male Ss from Chicago, 71 English-speaking urban, mixed race Ss from Chicago and 64 Spanish-speaking urban Ss from Chicago and Puerto Rico. The FAHI showed sufficient internal consistency reliability, concurrent validity, and sensitivity to change (STC). However, the 9-item HIV-specific subscale showed relatively low alpha coefficients and marginal STC, leading to supplementation of content with 11 more items, creating the FAHI version 3. The use of this new version in evaluating group differences and within-group change over time is encouraged. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Comments on the article by S. B. Timimi (see record # 84-26326) arguing that the paranoid-schizoid model (derived from Kleinian theory) is inadequate to examine the complexity of racism. It is suggested that the theoretical concepts are too narrow and limited to provide a complete understanding of racism. The paranoid-schizoid model needs to incorporate some common themes; in particular about the father, the symbolic world, guilt, envy, and the power of the group. column5: Race and colour in internal and external reality.
column11: British Journal of Psychotherapy. Vol.13(2), Win 1996, pp. 183-192.
column18: To understand the psychological origins and impact of racism, two assumptions are proposed. The first is that racism develops out of internal paranoid schizoid splits. The second relates to the manner in which these splits are organized. The history of racial exploitation provides powerful projection highways that can be used to maintain these internal splits. Reciprocal projective identification between internal and external white part-objects and internal and external black part-objects locates desirable aspects of the self in white objects and undesirable aspects in black objects. Some of the resulting complex defences and identifications are illustrated using case material. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Compared the effects of instrumental enrichment (IE) among 3 groups of 5th graders in segragated schools: 57 White children, 27 children of mixed race, and 37 Black children. The IE program was comprised of 14 paper-and-pencil instruments each focused on a different cognitive operation. Ss' teachers received workshops in the theory and practice of mediated learning experiences and a set of curriculum packages embodying IE concepts. Both prior to and following the IE program, Ss' performance was measured in the areas of intellectual ability, creativity, self-concept, and scholastic achievement. Postintervention improvements for all groups on cognitive measures were significant, with varying results on scholastic, creativity, and self-concept measures. The improvements were greatest among the Black Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Gender and race in a pro-feminist, progressive, mixed-gender, mixed-race organization.
column10: Ostrander, Susan A.: Tufts U, Dept of Sociology, Medford, MA, US
column11: Gender & Society. Vol.13(5), Oct 1999, pp. 628-642.
column18: Feminist researchers have urged more study of how feminist practice is actually accomplished in mixed-gender organizations. Social movement scholars have called for more attention to dynamics of gender and race in social movement organizations, especially to the challenges of maintaining internal solidarity. Based on field observations in a pro-feminist, progressive, mixed-gender, mixed-race social movement organization, this article examines organizational decision-making processes and interpersonal and group dynamics. From February 1990 to May 1992, the author attended meetings; conducted 40 in-depth interviews with board members, staff and donors; and innumerable informal conversations; and reviewed documents back to 1974. The data was reviewed for themes and patterns. Gendered and racialized patterns of subordination are both very much in evidence and, at the same time, actively challenged in this organization. The author argues that pro-feminist and progressive organizational practices and efforts to create solidarity across gender and race can exist through competing and contradictory dynamics and ongoing struggles. Complex and inconsistent dynamics around these social barriers are likely to occur in organizations more generally and need to be a subject for more research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Analyzed the factor structure of the Revised NEO Personality Inventory (NEO-PI-R) in 408 White, Black, Indian, and mixed race South African college students to see if the five-factor model can be recovered and determined the utility of the use of the test in South Africa and if a comparable factor structure can be recovered in White and Black South Africans. When the instrument was factor analyzed, the structure of the five-factor model was well reproduced for the entire sample as well as the White and Black subgroups. Parallel analysis indicated the appropriateness of the five-factor solution. Whereas the structure of personality was highly similar across race, there were statistically significant differences in mean scores of some domains and facets by race. The greatest difference was in Openness to Experience, particularly in the Openness to Feelings facet, with the White subgroup scoring relatively high, the Black subgroup scoring relatively low, and the Indian subgroup scoring in an intermediate range. The authors speculate that these differences are primarily the result of social, economic, and cultural differences between the races rather than the direct product of race itself. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: (from the chapter) I never wanted to be White growing up. It is a good thing because I was not. But now, I am almost White in some people's eyes. How this happened tells not only a piece of some of my life story but, in hindsight, has allowed some of my critical thinking around racial and ethnic identity formation. My transformation of color has not been my own doing but a reflection of a larger racial project in this country. Reflections on my racial transformation, raised by one parent not familiar with the racial system of the United States and the other having internalized the system so well, figured critically into how I have been able to think about identity formation. I had to for survival's sake--both in the world and to make sense out of the subtleties of human interaction. When I came to the United States with my mother as a small child, we were not White. My mother is a Filipina, not Filipina American, as she always reminds me even after 40-plus years. Whereas my father is a White American, he sustained some subtle and not so subtle demotions in status as a result of marrying a non-White person. In this chapter I share some of my personal and professional experiences as a mixed-race person. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Environmental mediation and hot interpretation: A case study of District Six, Cape Town.

column18: Explores implications and possibilities of a "hot interpretation" of apartheid structures, events, and society to bring about attitude change and reconciliation among race groups in South Africa. Hot interpretation is defined as the incorporation of emotion into interpretive displays and experiences. The aim of hot interpretation is to engage the public's attention and challenge them to examine their attitudes and actions with respect to social, environmental, and moral issues. District Six in Cape Town is used as an example for an apartheid interpretation and environmental mediation program. This district may be the best known example of the destruction of a mixed race community through Group Areas legislation in South Africa. The planning of a hot interpretive program or center for District Six must be community-driven and approved through a grassroots decision-making process. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: (from the chapter) This final chapter discusses psychotherapy in light of oppression due to gender, race and class. It reads in part: The important point for me as a psychotherapist is that this racist history has influenced how I see myself, the interest I take in my work, and what kind of work I do. It is no accident that most of my professional life has been spent working with mixed-race groups, exploring issues to do with black/white identity, and working with oppressed groups, because that is part of me. In contrast I must admit that another part of me was white supremacist-I was putting down black people and Asians as all Anglo Indians did, because they did not want to identify with the oppressed Asians. But although growing up in that kind of a family has taught me a lot, gut feeling just hasn't been enough. I have also had to look at how I could make use of existing theories and methods and work that has been done in the past. I am not going to be an apologist for psychotherapy. I would actually be harder than most on European, white psychotherapy because I have seen its tremendous failings and it has not given me enough-although I am a clinical psychologist with psychotherapy training-because its practice and its professional institutions are both severely limited and dominated by white Eurocentric thought. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Investigated whether differences exist in eating attitudes and body shape concerns among adolescent schoolgirls representing South Africa's ethnically and culturally diverse population currently undergoing epidemiological transition. A questionnaire survey, including the Eating Attitudes Test (EAT), Body Shape Questionnaire (BSQ) and a Body Silhouette Chart, was administered to 228 South African schoolgirls (60 black, 83 mixed race and 85 white) aged 15-18 yrs from 5 secondary schools in the greater Cape Town area. Black girls had significantly higher mean body mass index (BMI) values than either White or mixed race girls. Controlling for differences in BMI, White girls scored significantly higher on the BSQ than did mixed race or Black girls, whereas no ethnic differences were found for EAT scores. A comparable percentage of Black, mixed race and White girls had scores indicative of eating disorder pathology on the EAT, while a higher percentage of White, compared to mixed race and Black, girls had abnormal scores on the BSQ. The ideal body size desired by White girls was significantly smaller than that of the mixed race or Black samples. Dissatisfaction with present body size was significantly higher in White, compared to Black or mixed race girls. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Child: Care, Health and Development. Vol.27(1), Jan 2001, pp. 73-83.
column18: The aim of this study was to contribute to knowledge of the construct validity of the Griffiths Scales of Mental Development (Griffiths Scales) through an examination of the underlying dimensions tapped by the six subscales, using Common Factor Analysis. A sample of 430 South African children (aged 54-83 mo), from four ethnic groups (i.e. White, Mixed Race, Asian and Black) participated. The correlation coefficients obtained for the South African groups were compared to those Griffiths obtained in her work with the British standardization sample of the Griffiths Scales. The pattern of correlation for South African and British subjects was found to be similar. This suggests that the Scales are measuring a construct which is consistent across cultures and through time. A factor analysis was performed with the data for each South African ethnic group separately and the factor solutions were compared to determine whether the Griffiths Scales measure similar or different constructs for the groups. The results indicate that the Griffiths Scales tend to measure one factor, and including only common variables, the factor appears to be similar cross-culturally. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Using a life course perspective, this paper traces cigarette use over ages 13-17 yrs among a mixed-race sample of economically disadvantaged urban students. Compared to African American teens, cigarette use by white teens was much more prevalent. Still, experimentation with cigarettes (aged 13-14 yrs) was a powerful predictor of cigarette use at ages 15 and 17 for youth of both races, with those who were least engaged in school more likely to experiment at early ages. Employment during the school year predicted more use of cigarettes mainly by white males, with cigarette use by white females not related to employment. The number of African Americans in this sample who used cigarettes was so few that to analyze cigarette use in relation to employment is not possible. White male students were more disengaged from school, and more likely to be performing adult-type work than other students. This paper suggests they use cigarettes as a means to signal their acceleration of the adult transition. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Journal of the Gay & Lesbian Medical Assn. Vol.5(4), Dec 2001, pp. 155-162.
column18: Examined racial/ethnic differences in the prevalence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) risk behaviors among young men who have sex with men (YMSM) across the US. Face-to-face interviews were conducted among 2612 randomly selected Ss (aged 15-25) from 13 cities in venues identified with large samples of ethnic minority YMSM. The 13 sites were divided into 4 ethnic strata, within which only YMSM of 1 of the following ethnic backgrounds were recruited: African American, Asian/Pacific Islander, Hispanic, and mixed ethnicity. Results show that 22% of Ss reported that their last sexual contact with their main sexual partner, someone other than a main sexual partner, or both involved unprotected anal intercourse. Ss from Asian/Pacific Islander sites, mixed sites, and Hispanic sites were more likely than Ss from African American sites to report unprotected anal intercourse. Within the mixed sites, Hispanic Ss, followed by Asian/Pacific Islander and White Ss, were more likely than African American Ss to report unprotected anal intercourse. It is concluded that interventions are needed that are responsive to the racial/ethnic differences in HIV risk behaviors of YMSM throughout urban American cities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Peer acceptance and self-perceptions in children: The impact of gender and race.
column10: Trzepacz, Angie M.: U Cincinnati, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(5-B), Nov 2001, pp. 2505.
column18: This study examined the impact of gender and race on specific dimensions of self-perception and on the relationships between peer acceptance and dimensions of self-perception. In addition, the psychometric properties of the Self-Perception Profile for Children were examined for this population of children. The data included peer acceptance scores and self-perception profiles for 466 children between the ages of 7 and 15. Girls reported lower self-perceptions than boys on the dimensions of Athletic Competence and Physical Appearance, but higher self-perceptions for Behavioral Conduct. No gender differences were found for Global Self-Esteem or perceptions of Scholastic Competence or Social Acceptance. Black children had higher perceptions of Physical Appearance than White children but reported similar scores on the other five dimensions. No interaction effects for gender and race were identified for any of the dimensions of self-perception. Peer acceptance was positively correlated with perceived Social Acceptance and Global Self-Esteem. There were no significant main effects of gender or race for any of the correlations between peer acceptance and dimensions of self-perception. A significant interaction effect was identified for the relationship between peer acceptance and perceptions of Physical Appearance: the relationship between peer acceptance and perceived physical appearance was significantly stronger for Black boys than for each of the other three groups. The evaluation of the Self-Perception Profile for Children indicated that its psychometric properties are acceptable for Black and White children of both genders. These results suggest that for children in America, gender and race do not generally have a significant clinical impact on specific dimensions of self-perception or on the relationships between self-perceptions and peer acceptance. In addition, the gender effects found here for a mixed-race group are generally in agreement with prior research, which was conducted using mostly White samples. This finding suggests that self-perceptions and the relationships between self-perceptions and peer acceptance are not race-specific. Although some gender and race differences were statistically significant, the effect sizes were small in all cases. Therefore, the few identified differences should be kept in perspective, and attention should be focused on the overwhelming similarities among these groups of children. This project was supported by a 12-month Dissertation Research Grant in Child and Adolescent Developmental Psychopathology from the National Institute of Mental Health. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The relationship of community attitudes toward battered wives to the race of the victim and the racial mix of the couple.
column10: Meade, Linda Lee: U Missouri - Saint Louis, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(2-B), Aug 2001, pp. 1091.
column18: Non-white battered women, and victims in mixed-race relationships, may encounter more negative attitudes than their white or same-race counterparts. Attitudes toward battered wives, as related to the race of the victim and the racial mix of the couple, were examined in the present study. It was predicted that participants (a) would view the black victim differently than the white victim, and (b) would view the victim in an interracial couple differently than the victim in a same race couple. In addition, it was predicted that (c) participants who had been victims of domestic violence would have more positive attitudes toward the victim, and (d) participants would have more negative attitudes toward victims of their own race. Two hundred and ninety-four participants read domestic violence scenarios and viewed obscured photographs in which the race of the victim and the racial mix of the couple were varied. After reading the scenario, each participant completed the Adjective Check List describing traits of the victim. Participants also completed the Revised Conflict Tactics Scale to provide information regarding domestic violence experience. The majority of participants had never been victims or perpetrators of domestic violence at any point in their lives. There were significant associations between lifetime and current domestic violence experience and participant race and education. The data failed to provide support for the hypotheses. Men saw victims significantly more negatively than women, and participants saw victims of their own race less negatively than victims of the other race. Results are discussed in relationship to previous studies examining attitudes toward victims, experience with domestic violence, and racial issues. Implications and recommendations for future research are presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: This study investigated possible associations between ethnic background of referred children and non-attendance, referrer type, problem type, age and gender. The sample consisted of 769 children (aged 15 yrs or under) offered outpatient appointments. Ethnic background influenced referrer type. Over-referrals against expectations were: White children more by GPs than expected, Black and South Asian children by specialist doctors, Black children by education services and Mixed Race children by social services. There was neither a significant difference in ethnic background between attendees and non-attendees nor were gender, age or problem types related to ethnic group. Clinicians should be aware that referral routes may appropriately, or inappropriately, be different for different ethnic groups. Differences found may be due to genuine variations in morbidity, thus leading to presentation to different referrers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Parental divorce and children's interpersonal relationships: A meta-analysis. [References].
column10: Kunz, Jenifer: West Texas A&M U, Dept of Behavioral Sciences, Canyon, TX, US
column11: Journal of Divorce & Remarriage. Vol.34(3-4), 2001, pp. 19-47.
column18: This meta-analysis involved 53 studies that compared the interpersonal relationships (parents, siblings, and peers) of children (aged 6-25 yrs) from divorced homes with those from continuously intact homes. Children from divorced homes had more positive sibling relationships than children from intact homes. Mixed-race samples of children had more negative interpersonal relationships than white samples of children. Younger children from divorced homes experienced a lower quality of mother-child relationship than older children. The quality of relationships are lower for studies conducted more recently when compared with those conducted in earlier decades. Larger samples and studies utilizing attitude measures yielded stronger evidence for a lower quality of interpersonal relationship. Effect sizes were stronger for clinical samples than in studies based on convenience or random samples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Examined cultural factors influencing perceptions of body size in 1,139 14-17 yr olds of different ethnic groups in Trinidad and Tobago. Ss, who were mainly South Asian, African, and individuals of mixed race, completed a questionnaire on desired body size and the factors that influenced their choice. There were significant gender differences in desired body size. The majority (83%) of females wanted to be a normal size, 4% overweight and 13% desiring to be underweight. Among males, 66% wanted to be normal-sized, 31% overweight, and 2% underweight. There were no ethnic differences in desired body weight. The main influences of desired body size in females were movie stars, fashion models, and sport personalities. Among males, the most important influences were sports personalities and movie stars. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: American Educational Research Journal. Vol.37(1), Spr 2000, pp. 33-65.
column18: Examined the conversational styles employed by students attending a desegregated middle school while discussing race. Students discussed issues related to race in focus groups initially comprised solely of White, Black, or nondominant individuals. Subsequently, subjects (Ss) then convened in mixed-race groups, with conversation styles examined. Results show that Ss employed 2 distinct types of conversational styles. In the 1st type, which may be labeled "bridging talk", Ss used multiple strategies to build unity across differences. In the 2nd type, "conflict talk," Ss discursively created borders and conflict. Findings suggest promises and challenges for each type of discussion. A 3rd form for consideration, "democratic conversation," would invite perspectives while acknowledging the privileging and silencing that accompany them. It is concluded that educators should hold conversations that explicitly address the power dynamics inherent in such conversations and teach the conceptual tools and language to identify these dynamics. Although these conversations across racial lines are sometimes threatening and difficult, they are a critical component of democratic education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A descriptive study of the effects of exposure to violence in an inner city community on aspects of adolescent identity development during this critical phase.
column10: Schiavone, Deborah Burdett: The Catholic U America, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(4-B), Oct 2000, pp. 1876.
column18: Inner city youths are at particular risk for violence. The social effects of violence on our adolescents have profound implications on their development, now and as they mature into adulthood. The purpose of this study was to describe the effects of exposure to violence in an inner city community on aspects of adolescent identity development during this critical phase. The collection of data was pursued to answer specific questions: (a) what are adolescents' experiences with exposure to violence in their community as revealed in their self narratives, (b) what interpretations and meanings do adolescents ascribe to their exposure to violence in the community, (c) how does exposure to violence affect adolescents' self image, view of a just and benevolent world, value of human life, ideology of right and wrong, and thoughts of their future? The conceptual orientation for this study was psychobiography, or life history. Personal narratives are significant resources for understanding individual persons. The ascribed meanings for life experiences influence how persons organize their self identity. The methodology for this study was a qualitative exploratory design that used a non-probability sample. Young adults between the ages of 18 and 21 were recruited from inner city community programs. Data were collected from a demographic sheet and written transcripts of audio-taped stories. The chronological arrangement of events of exposure on an Age Line helped participants organize their stories. Data were analyzed according to the methodologies of narrative and constant comparative analysis. Thirteen participants, 11 Blacks, 1 Hispanic, 1 Mixed race, completed the study by telling their personal stories describing their exposure to community violence. The numbers of exposures to community violence ranged from 2 to 6 per person. The young persons in this study used coping strategies of distrust, detachment, distraction, and minimization. A major theme was one of oppression. Further research is needed to expand the knowledge of the impact of violence on adolescent identity development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The interracial experience: Growing up Black/White racially mixed in the United States. [References].
column10: Brown, Ursula M.: Private Practice, Montclair, NJ, US
column11: (2000). The interracial experience: Growing up Black/White racially mixed in the United States. x, 153 pp. Westport, CT, US: Greenwood Press/Greenwood Publishing Group; US.
column18: (from the publicity materials) Investigates how mixed race people cope in a world that has shoehorned them into a racial category that denies half of their physiological and psychological existence. The author presents relevant demographic, research, and sociocultural data as well as a series of personal vignettes based on interviews with 119 American-born black/white interracial young adults (mean age of 21.4 yrs) from all walks of life. The author interweaves research findings with these interviews in order to highlight certain psychosocial phenomenon and experiences. The history of interracial marriages in the US is examined, and the scientific and social theories that underlie the racial bigotry suffered by mixed people are discussed. Questions of racial identity, conflict, and self-esteem are addressed and treated as issues of mental health, and the struggle for acceptance in a black and white world and the racist abuses that many interracial people have suffered are discussed as well. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Gambling and correlates of gambling among Minnesota public school students.
column10: Stinchfield, Randy: U Minnesota, MN, US
column11: Journal of Gambling Studies. Vol.16(2-3), Fal 2000, pp. 153-173.
column18: Examines the prevalence of gambling and measures the relationships between gambling behavior and a number of demographic, psychosocial, and behavioral variables among 78,582 male and female Minnesota public school 9th and 12th graders. Ss completed the 1998 Minnesota Student Survey, a 121-item, questionnaire that inquires about multiple health-related content domains, including gambling behavior. The majority of students had gambled at least once during the past year, however, most students did not report gambling frequently, nor did they report problems associated with their gambling. Boys reported gambling more often than girls, and older students gambled more often than younger students. A larger percentage of Mexican/Latin American, African American, American Indian, and mixed race students gambled at weekly and daily rates than Asian American and Caucasian students. Variables associated with gambling frequency included antisocial behavior, gender (being a male), alcohol and tobacco use, age, feeling bad about the amount of money they bet, a desire to stop gambling, and increased sexual activity. Gambling appears to be related to other risk-taking behaviors and may be a part of the adolescent experimentation with adult behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Standing on both feet: History and the construction of identity for older mixed-race Americans. (elderly).
column10: Tashiro, Cathy J.: U California, San Francisco, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.60(4-A), Oct 1999, pp. 1345.
column18: People of mixed heritage promise to be a significant percentage of the U.S. population in the 21st century. However, as a group, they have not been well studied. Previous research has tended to focus on identity in children, adolescents and young adults. This dissertation is based on a study of a sector of the mixed race population that has been less visible; those who were middle aged and elderly at the time the research was done in the late 1990's. The primary method of data collection was through focused life histories of 20 people of mixed race whose ages ranged from 45 to 94. The participants were either of African American/White or Asian American/White background. The study examines factors influencing identity and identification, and how the meaning of being of mixed race is influenced by aging, different historical circumstances, and the race of the non-white parent. A synthesis of elements of racial formation, cultural studies, symbolic interactionist, and life course theories provided the theoretical framework for interpreting the findings of the study. Racial identity did not emerge as a singular, distinct entity in this study. The meaning of being of mixed race is influenced by other aspects of social location such as age, gender, class and nation. Using grounded theory techniques, five dimensions of racial identity emerged: cultural identity, ascribed racial identity, racial identification to others, racial self-identification, and situational racialization of feeling. The age cohort of the participant (older or younger than 65) and the race of the nonwhite parent (Black or Asian American) were associated with different patterns of identity dimensions. These patterns are attributed to the influence of historical circumstances on identity. The dissertation provides an overview of significant events in African American and Asian American history and how they intersect with critical points in the life courses of the two age cohorts. This work demonstrates that racial identity for mixed race people cannot be understood outside of social and historical context. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Claiming space: The college experience of biracial and multiracial students on predominantly white campuses.
column10: Renn, Kristen Avard: Boston Coll, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.59(8-A), Feb 1999, pp. 2886.
column18: This ethnographic study explored the experience of bi- and multiracial college students at three predominantly white, private, residential institutions in New England. Data consisted of individual interviews with twenty-four participants aged 18-23 (eight per institution), their written responses to two prompts, a focus group at each institution, and observations of campus climate. The research questions were: (1) What factors in the college environment are most salient to multiracial students in their racial identity development? (2) How do multiracial college students understand their racial identity options in college? There were two main findings in this study: how various factors outside and inside the college environment impacted students' identity development and how the campus environment mediated the options available for students to identify racially. Five patterns of racial self-identification among the students emerged. Multiracial students' experience was shaped by their ability to fit into existing groups within the community of students of color, to create a separate group of mixed race students, or both. The three main factors influencing students' ability to fit in were the size and location of the community of students of color in relation to the general campus milieu and the forces of peer culture that facilitated or inhibited movement among and between the public spaces students constructed on campus. This study links the fields of college student development theory and emerging theories about multiraciality through the introduction of an ecology model for understanding multiracial identity development in college students. This study also raises concerns about the use of racial categories in higher education and in the United States as a whole. Finally, this study suggests a number of areas for further research in college student development, multiracial identity development, and race-based policy in higher education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Of Jewel Heritage: Racial socialization and racial identity attitudes amongst adolescents of mixed African-Caribbean/White parentage.
column10: Fatimilehin, Iyabo A.: Royal Liverpool Children's NHS Trust, Child & Family Services, Liverpool, England
column11: Journal of Adolescence. Vol.22(3), Jun 1999, pp. 303-318.
column18: Investigated 23 British 12-19 yr olds of mixed racial parentage regarding their attitudes about being Black. Most Ss had 1 White parent and 1 African-Caribbean parent.Tests communally administered included the Racial Identity Attitude Scale, the Teenager Experience of Racial Socialization, the Rosenberg Self-esteem Inventory, and the Socio-demographic Questionnaire. Results showed that Ss have a positive sense of racial identity concerning their Black heritage. Older Ss demonstrated more internalized attitudes. Only the racial socialization scales indicated any effect of primary caregiver. Ss living with both parents reported receiving more racial socialization messages, especially in terms of proactive messages. There were no significant differences between males and females. Ss demonstrated a positive racial identity while simultaneously claiming dual identification; this ability increased with age and was associated with high self-esteem. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Eating attitudes among black South Africans.
column11: The American Journal of Psychiatry. Vol.156(6), Jun 1999, pp. 981-982.
column18: Comments on the article by D. le Grange et al (see record 1997-41469-015) on the eating attitudes and behaviors of Caucasian and non-Caucasian South African college students and presents additional data on eating attitudes among black South Africans. The author has been involved in the treatment of 9 black female South Africans with eating disorders and notes the absence of any unique features designating the sufferers as black. These observations suggest that, within the urban setting, there is a homogenization of eating-related psychopathology across racial groups. In a sample of 213 adolescent female South African private school students, the author found that 20.7% of white Ss and 37.5% of black Ss were classified as having abnormal eating attitudes based on their responses to the Eating Attitudes Test. 18.6% of black and white adolescent government school students (N = 1,353) also showed abnormal eating attitudes. The author suggests that it is clear that, within the broader South African community, eating attitudes exist that place a significant proportion of adolescents and young adults of all racial groups at risk for the development of eating disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effects of proportional representation on intragroup behavior in mixed-race decision-making groups.
column9:
Li, Ji

Karakowsky, Leonard

Siegel, Jacob P
column10: Li, Ji: Hong Kong Baptist U, School of Business, Hong Kong
column11: Small Group Research. Vol.30(3), Jun 1999, pp. 259-279.
column18: Drawing on Kanter's (1977) observations and assertions, this study employs a structural approach to examine the influence of group racial composition on the behavior of group members. To be specific, this study assesses the effects of proportional representation on the behavior of 90 Asian group members who were assigned to one of three types of groups: all-Asian groups, Asian-Caucasian balanced groups, and Caucasian-dominated groups. Groups were assigned the task of discussing and generating a solution for a managerial case scenario. The discussions were videotaped and viewed by independent judges who evaluated patterns of intragroup behavior including levels of participation and leadership behavior among group members. The findings suggest that proportional representation can act as a significant source of influence on behavior of group members. We conclude this article with a discussion of the implications of these findings from both a practical and theoretical perspective. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Case study of a 19-year-old female sexually abused as a child.
column10: Dillon, Catherine M.: Objective/Projective Tests, Inc., Brooklandville, MD, US
column11: Karp, Stephen A [Ed]. (1999). Studies of objective/projective personality tests.  (pp. 139-148). 160 pp. Brooklandville, MD, US: Objective/Projective Tests; US.
column18: (from the chapter) Monta, a 19-yr-old female of mixed race, was sexually abused by men living with her mother between ages 6 and 12. Pregnant at 16 she dropped out of school, went on welfare, entered a therapy support group for abuse victims, and is currently attempting to finish high school. She volunteered to take a battery of tests for the author and took the Draw-A-Person Questionnaire (S. A. Karp, 1990, 1999), Karp Objective Word Association Test (Karp, 1996) and the Apperceptive Personality Test: Brief Adult (Karp et al, 1993). Findings are compared and contrasted across tests. The author concludes that Monta's results reflect many problems, the most consistent reflecting emotional immaturity and distorted views of sex. Despite the negative life experiences, her outlook is comparatively positive. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Whiteness as stigma: Essentialist identity work by mixed-race women.
column10: Storrs, Debbie: U Idaho, Dept of Anthropology/Sociology, Moscow, ID, US
column11: Symbolic Interaction. Vol.22(3), 1999, pp. 187-212.
column18: Explains the reversal of the racial mixing problem as well as the identity work of women as they rearticulate the meaning of race and racial belonging within dominant racial logic. The identification of macro constraints and the illustration of individual agency in the negotiation of identity extends the symbolic interactionist perspective on identity formation. The author captures the micro level social process of racial formation through an analysis of women's ability to rearticulate the meaning of stigma. This research also adds to the symbolic interactionist literature that emphasizes face-to-face interaction, the micro processes, in the construction of self by revealing the dynamic interplay between macro and micro processes in the development of racial identity. The date used are drawn from a larger study that examines the racial and gendered identity constructions of 27 mixed-race women living in the US. The women in this study reject dominant patterns of stigma by reassigning stigma to their European ancestry. Given this reversal, women articulate and embrace non-white identities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:

Rivera, Semilla M
