column11: Journal of Social and Personal Relationships. Vol.16(1), Feb 1999, pp. 65-86.
column18: In an attempt to comprehend the perceptions held about racially similar and dissimilar couples, 4 issues were examined. First, differences in perceptions based on the couple's racial composition were investigated. It was hypothesized that perceptions about the couple, its members, and its relationship quality would be more positive for same-race dyads than mixed-race couples. Second, the authors examined the impact of intimacy level on perceptions of these dyads. Pairs who were friends were predicted to receive more positive perceptions than the engaged couples. Third, it was hypothesized that racially dissimilar couples who were engaged would be perceived more negatively than the racially similar friend and engaged dyads and the racially dissimilar friend pairs. Lastly, the authors looked at the possible sex- and race-of-the-perceiver effects on perceptions of these dyads. Ss were 207 undergraduates. Results supported the 1st and 2nd hypotheses, and there was partial evidence for the last. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multicultural psychotherapy: An approach to individual and cultural differences (2nd ed.).
column10: Ramirez, Manuel: U Texas, Austin, TX, US
column11: (1999). Multicultural psychotherapy: An approach to individual and cultural differences (2nd ed.). xii, 236 pp. Needham Heights, MA, US: Allyn & Bacon; US.
column18: (from the preface) This book explores a model of counseling and psychotherapy based on the multicultural perspective that evolved from the author's work with "the different." It introduces 5 new case studies to supplement the 5 presented in the earlier edition and includes a chapter on family therapy that adds insights into counseling and/or therapy for mixed-race couples. A new chapter has also been added on how the multicultural model can be useful in meeting guidelines introduced through managed care. The principal objectives of the model are to help people who feel different and alienated accept and understand their uniqueness. The model also seeks to enhance cultural values and to develop flexibility in cognitive styles. Although its primary focus is on ethnic/racial minorities, the model is appropriate for members of any group that differs from the societal ideal. The ultimate goal of this model is the development of a multicultural orientation to life. The techniques and strategies reflect an eclecticism, ranging from the intensive study of the client's life history and the use of insight, to the employment of cognitive behavioral as well as humanistic and cross-cultural approaches. Multicultural therapy, however, is unique in its theoretical concepts and goals for change. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interactions on an elementary school playground: Variations by age, gender, race, group size, and playground area.
column9:
Lewis, Tracey E

Phillipsen, Leslie C
column10: Lewis, Tracey E.: U Memphis, Ctr for Research in Educational Policy, Memphis, TN, US
column11: Child Study Journal. Vol.28(4), 1998, pp. 309-320.
column18: Children in two age groups (88 first- and second graders and 76 fifth- and sixth graders) were observed in a study of elementary school playground interactions. A time-sampling procedure was used to record the gender, race, and group size of all interactive play in seven playground areas during each age group's recess period. Older children played in same-gender, larger groups more than the younger children did. Girls and boys were equally likely to play in same- and mixed-race groupings. While both same- and mixed-gender interaction was more likely to be mixed- rather than same-race, mixed-gender interaction was much more likely to include more than one race than all girls' or all boys' interactions. Mixed-race interactions also included more children than same-race interactions. Other analyses examined variations in playground area by age, gender, race, and group size. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Socioeconomic status, ethnicity, knowledge of child development, maturity, and stress as related to parenting attitudes in adolescent mothers.
column10: Kenrick, Helena Eckerberg: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(6-B), Dec 1998, pp. 3094.
column18: This study examines the relationship of socioeconomic status, ethnic group, knowledge of child development, maturity, and stress to parenting attitudes in adolescent mothers. This research expands on previous studies by combining the aforementioned variables, which have previously been analyzed only separately in the literature, and relating them to parenting attitudes. This study also examines whether a new construct proposed by this author--"cooperative parenting" (or instrumental, emotional, and financial support)--is related to ethnic group and stress levels for adolescent mothers. It was predicted that there would be a significant positive relationship between socioeconomic status, maturity, knowledge of child development, and authoritative parenting, as well as a significant negative relationship between these variables and authoritarian parenting. Further, a significant negative relationship was predicted between stress, authoritative parenting, and cooperative parenting. It was also predicted that Latina adolescent mothers would use cooperative parenting more than Caucasian adolescent mothers. Participants came from low socioeconomic backgrounds and lived in rural communities in northern California. They were recruited through two statewide intervention programs run by the Department of Social Services and Department of Public Health. A total of 81 mothers participated in the study. The participation rate was 34%. The sample included 30 Latina; 28 Caucasian; 5 African-American; and 18 "Other" (Asian, Native American, or mixed race) adolescent mothers. A principal components analysis was undertaken on scores on the predictor variables (stress, knowledge of child development, maturity, ethnic group, and socioeconomic status), in order to create composite scores. Two factors, mother's "Well Functioning", (yielding high maturity and low stress) and mother's "Knowledge of Child Development" emerged from this analysis. These two factors were then regressed on the criterion (authoritarian parenting). Findings suggested that high stress, together with low maturity and low knowledge of child development, was related to more authoritarian parenting. There was no significant relationship between authoritarian parenting and socioeconomic status for this sample. The hypothesis that cooperative parenting and stress would be inversely related was partly supported. Of the three domains of cooperative parenting, financial support was associated with higher stress for this sample. Conversely, more instrumental support was related to lower stress, whereas emotional support did not appear to significantly relate to stress levels for this sample. Independent t-tests between groups revealed that Latina mothers were characterized by more instrumental and emotional support relative to their Caucasian peers. General limitations of the study were reviewed and clinical implications of the results discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Free of memory, free of longing: Stories and reflections on a mixed-race self.
column10: Katayama, Kyoko: The Union Inst, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(12-B), Jun 1998, pp. 6845.
column18: This is a multi-genre--narrative, poetry, journal writing, and essays--exploration on mixed-race identity and self. The subject of the re/search is the authors "self" through her dual roots and shifting cultural locations of identities in multiple contexts. The deeply felt re/search question throughout the paper is: How do we negotiate the enduring and changing, universal and local, common and different, cultural and spiritual dimensions of our existence, which interface, sometimes colliding, in us as individuals and in our social systems? The author examines how the approaches toward human differences in the United States have been influenced by the epistemologies of the Western philosophical traditions, which tend to privilege rationality and individual ego. She proposes a way of approaching our differences through embodied epistemologies, increased self-and-other awareness, and appreciation of our web-like interconnections. The first chapter, Journeys and Landscapes, deals with the beginning of the purposeful search for self. Her journeys are characterized by a longing for the elusive home and the many hindrances that make the journey home treacherous. The second chapter, Birthing, explores the cultural, historical, and psychological context of her birth on her Japanese mother's side. Delivering, the third chapter, documents how finding and meeting for the first time in her life her European American birth-father jarred the construction and the development of her sense of self and identities. The final chapters, Essays, are the author's attempts to make meaning by theorizing and integrating her life experiences with extensive reading in feminist writing, postmodern thought, cultural studies, cross-cultural and transpersonal psychology. The writing is intensely personal and autobiographical, yet the author's commitment to honesty, self-reflection, and scholarship also make the work politically and socially transformative. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Communicating prejudice in the media: Upending racial categories in Doubles.
column10: Ono, Kent O.: U California, Davis, CA, US
column11: Hecht, Michael L [Ed]. (1998). Communicating prejudice.  (pp. 206-220). ix, 404 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column18: (from the introduction) This chapter examines how prejudice is communicated in the media. The author focuses his discussion on representations of race and seeks an analytic frame that avoids recreating the system it attempts to critique. He seeks to articulate a lens for explicating media that neither embraces racialization and racial divisions nor accepts a priori racial definitions that maintain existing hierarchies. After reviewing the predominant trends in research on media representations of race (good-bad representations, discrimination, pedagogy about race, audience reception, images and stereotypes, and uses and gratifications), he describes recent trends that examine Whiteness, diaspora, exhilic experiences, and "otherness." From these trends, he builds his discussion based on the assumption that media representations are sites of political contestation involving disparities of power. He is concerned about how media images participate in the construction of political realities in addition to reflecting social practice. He uses a text, Doubles, which problematizes binary, essentializing racial purity by focusing on bi- and mixed-race people to challenge images of racial purity and unpack the practice of substituting "American" for "White." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:

Franklin, Cynthia

Bennett, Patricia
column10: Corcoran, Jacqueline: U Texas, School of Social Work, Arlington, TX, US
column11: Research on Social Work Practice. Vol.8(3), May 1998, pp. 302-314.
column18: The psychometric properties of a multidimensional measure of social support, A. Vaux's Social Support Behaviors Scale (SS-B), were evaluated. The SS-B is represented by subscales describing 5 central categories of supportive behaviors (Emotional, Socializing, Practical, Financial, and Advice/Guidance), assessed for both friends and family. The SS-B was administered to a low SES, mixed-race (19% Anglo, 37% African American, and 40% Hispanic) sample of 105 adolescents who were attending pregnancy prevention programs. A trend toward high scores, low variance, and few differences between pregnant/parenting and nonpregnant/parenting teens were found on subscale scores. Factor analyses on separate subscales showed loadings more consistently for "family" than "friends." Overall results of psychometric analysis indicate that the scale needs further work to more accurately assess the salient behavioral dimensions of social support for samples from varying racial and socioeconomic backgrounds. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Examined the presence and severity of eating disorder pathology in students representing South Africa's ethnically and culturally diverse population. A questionnaire survey, which involved the Eating Attitude Test and the Bulimic Investigatory Test, was administered to 1,435 South African college students (739 Caucasian, 403 Black, 146 Asian, and 147 mixed race; aged 17-25 yrs) from 6 universities in 2 urban centers. Black Ss scored significantly higher than the other ethnic groups on these measures. In addition, a comparable percentage of Black and Caucasian women had scores within the clinical range on these scales. Men scored consistently lower than women. Findings challenge the notion that eating disorders are primarily a Western, Caucasian phenomenon and raise the possibility that the risk of eating disorders may increase in developing societies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18:
(from the introduction) This guide reviews the evolution and development of the current situation on gay and lesbian marriage, with a focus on psychological, political, and legal issues. While one of the chapters focuses on religious and spiritual issues regarding same-sex marriage, most of the focus is on civil marriage because of the benefits bestowed on it by local, state, and federal governments. The book also examines the political and legal issues involved in seeking same-sex marriage. Various chapters explore how and why gay people form relationships, how gay relationships differ from "straight" relationships, and what the impact may be with legally sanctioned same-sex marriage on a variety of emotional, psychological, legal, and child rearing issues.
(from the jacket) The contributors probe the harmful psychological effects that denying marital status has on same-sex couples, as well as on society as a whole. They also argue that same-sex marriage is not a moral issue, but a civil rights issue involving equal treatment and non-discrimination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The Myth of "Race" (and "Mixed Race"). [References].
column10:
Fairchild, Halford H.: Pitzer College, Claremont, CA, US
Rodriguez, Norma: Pitzer College, Claremont, CA, US
column11: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.42(7), Jul,  1997
column18: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1997, Vol 42(7), 620-621. American Mixed Race: The Culture of Microdiversity (see record 1995-97907-000), edited by Naomi Zack, probes this problem of the color line from the perspective of racial diversity within individuals. The book argues that discussions of diversity (i.e., racial difference, multiculturalism) tend to focus on rigidly defined racial categories that impose group membership for individuals who differ from others in those groups and who may not belong to, or identify with, any particular group. The important contributions of American Mixed Race are twofold. First, the book is multidisciplinary. Contributors represent a number of specialties within the social sciences and humanities. The five sections of the book are autobiography, art, social science, public policy, and identity theory. Second, the book demonstrates the breadth of the microdiversity concept. Although racial distinctions will remain salient within the broader social culture well into the 21st century, the real challenge is recognizing and appreciating the commonalities within human experiences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Shades of community and conflict: Biracial adults of African-American and Jewish-American heritages.
column10: Segal, Josylyn Chan: The Wright Inst, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(4-B), Oct 1997, pp. 2181.
column18: This study of eighteen adults of African-American and Jewish-American heritage explores how biracial subjects of two minority parents negotiates mixed race heritage and identity in a society that maintains a hostile attitude toward interracial unions. Data collection included (1) a semi-structured interview to determine subjects' own sense of racial/ethnic identity, (2) a measure of parental closeness, and (3) a series of twelve anecdotal hypothetical situations as a stimulus to revealing subjects' affective, cognitive and behavioral responses in contexts in which the subjects mixed-heritage might be expected to evoke conflict. A qualitative analysis, incorporating socio-cultural, psychodynamic, and historical perspectives, was utilized to investigate (1) racial and cultural stereotyping, (2) a hierarchy of color and racial categorization, (3) racial tolerance, (4) Black and Jewish relations, (5) biracial (Black and Jewish) identity, as mediated by parental and familial closeness. Factors that influenced racial/identity development in the subjects' lives were identified. Five of the six hypotheses were supported: (1) Phenotype is related to interpersonal perception. The biracial adult phenotypically perceived as African-American is more likely to identify as such, whereas the biracial adult phenotypically perceived as White is more likely to identify as either White or "mixed." (2) Closeness to the African-American parent is not necessary for children of mixed-race/Jewish heritage to identity with African-American heritage. (3) Closeness to the Jewish parent is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for children of mixed-race/Jewish heritage to identity with Jewish heritage. (4) For those who are close to their Jewish parent, the degree of closeness affects the degree to which they identify as Jews. (5) The extent to which respondents experience themselves as integral parts of their extended families will increase the extent to which they identify with that half of their cultural heritage. The sixth hypothesis, which stated that to the degree that respondents express negative stereotypes of one part of their heritage they will also minimize their identification with that part of their heritage was not supported due chiefly to the lack of negative stereotyping by most of the respondents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effects of conflict management style on discrimination during mixed-race interpersonal conflict.
column10: Grossman, Michele Marie: Texas A&M U, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(8-B), Feb 1997, pp. 5388.
column18: The present investigation was an effort to link the study of racial discrimination with interpersonal conflict. Specifically, this study focused on the effects that different styles of conflict management have on discrimination between two individuals experiencing a mixed-race dispute. One-hundred-twenty male subjects were paired with a same- or different-race confederate who displayed an avoidant, contentious, or cooperative conflict management style. It was hypothesized that subjects would perceive group boundaries, report negative stereotypes, prejudice attitudes, ingroup bias, negative internal attributions, and perceived dissimilarity, and demonstrate negative nonverbal affect and arousal during conflicts with a different-race partner using a contentious conflict style. These same responses, at a lesser intensity, were expected to be invoked by avoidant conflict styles and minimized by cooperative conflict ones. Results indicated that subjects exhibit the discrimination responses significantly more frequently when interacting with a different-race than same-race confederate displaying a contentious or avoidant conflict style. Conversely, cooperative conflict management minimized the discrimination responses. The findings of this investigation have strong implications for research conducted in both areas of interpersonal conflict and intergroup relations, as well as consequences for real-world, mixed-race disputes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(8-B), Feb 1997, pp. 5361.
column18: This study examined the relationship between social cognition, motivation, and social competence in children. Eighty fourth- through seventh-grade children, from three elementary and one middle school, participated in the study. A structured interview procedure, the Interpersonal Negotiation Strategies Interview, was used to assess children's social-cognition. The Social Self-Regulation questionnaire, used to assess motivation, was a self-report measure of the extent to which children perceived their social behaviors as autonomous. To measure social competence, the participants in the study were rated by their classroom teacher on the Interpersonal Negotiation Strategies Rating Scale. Children's sociometric status and discipline referrals were also used as measures of social competence. Contrary to the hypotheses, social cognition did not predict ratings on social competence measures. However, there were differences in children's interpersonal styles that predicted teachers' ratings of their social competence. Children with self-transforming or assertive interpersonal styles were more likely to be rated favorably by their teachers than were children with other-transforming or submissive and collaborative interpersonal styles. The impact of motivation on social competence measures was significant. In the sample of African-American, White, Latino, and Mixed-Race children, externally motivated boys were less likely to be selected as popular. African-American males, who were more intrinsically motivated than either Other-Race males and females, were more likely to be rated unfavorably by their teachers. They were also the only children to receive discipline referrals. Yet, within this group of African-American males, the older intrinsically motivated boys received fewer discipline referrals than their younger intrinsically motivated counterparts. There was a significant relationship between social cognition and motivation: Intrinsic motivational orientation was asso (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Reading, vocabulary and language preference in 7- to 8-year-old bilingual Asian children.
column10: Beech, John R.: U Leicester, Psychology Dept, England
column11: British Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.67(4), Dec 1997, pp. 405-414.
column18: Investigated the preference of Asian children to use their parental language over English in various contexts, such as when counting, by means of a questionnaire completed by a group of 40 bilingual Asian children that was compared with an age-matched mixed race monolingual group of 24 children (aged 7 and 8 yrs for both groups). SES was low. Group allocation was based on a specially devised Language Preference Questionnaire (LPQ) examining different contexts of language use (e.g., during numerical analysis). Standardized tests of non-verbal intelligence, vocabulary, basic reading, reading comprehension and the LPQ were given. Results indicate that controlling for non-verbal intelligence, there was a marked difference in receptive oral vocabulary and a weaker difference in reading ability between the 2 groups. The LPQ show that bilingual children who reported thinking in their parental language had poorer English vocabulary development than bilingual children who preferred to think in English. These findings are discussed in terms of either an effect of frequency of exposure to language or in terms of differences in phonological development between the 2 groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Women and the psychotherapeutic "color line". [References].
column10: Reid, Pamela Trotman: City University of New York, Graduate School and University Center, New York, NY, US
column11: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.41(1), Jan,  1996
column18: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1996, Vol 41(1), 19-20. Is there a "color line" in psychotherapy? Certainly there are stereotypes developed and preserved by psychological theorists and therapists that serve as expressions of established expectations and assumptions. These have, it is argued in this book (see record 1994-98466-000), prevented adequate treatment and service delivery to women who do not fit their image of a model client. The color line, a term drawn from recent U.S. history, was an actual demarcation drawn down hallways and waiting rooms to keep "colored people" (as Blacks and others were designated) separate from Whites as part of enforced segregation. This compendium of conceptual analyses, case examples, and suggestions for therapy invites those who would address the therapeutic needs of women to consider change. The goal of this book, which is well conceived and carefully organized, is to alert therapists to the changing realities of the U.S. demographics and prepare them to deliver services to an increasingly diverse population. This book makes a respectable effort at covering the topics of importance for women of the major ethnic groups now in the United States. As it stands, they include chapters on at least six ethnic groups (African Americans, American Indians, Asians, Latinas, women from the Caribbean, and women from India) and five special populations (professionals, lesbians, women of mixed race, refugees, and women who are battered). If there is any major omission, it is the surprising lack of any detailed discussion of the therapist-client relationship. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effects of family functioning on the psychological and social adjustment of Jamaican immigrant children.
column10: Hohn, Gabriela Emmi: Columbia U, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(5-B), Nov 1996, pp. 3411.
column18: This study investigated factors contributing to resiliency among Jamaican children in New York City. Jamaican families are unique in that they are frequently "transnational;" mothers often migrate several years before their children can join them, so that the family physically extends across national boundaries. Participants were 99 mothers (or other female caregivers) from Jamaica, ranging in age from 25 to 62 years, and their children (N = 120; 60 girls and 60 boys), aged 7 to 12. All were Black or of mixed race. Three groups of children were studied (N = 40 each): Group 1 (born in the U.S.); Group 2 (migrated with mothers); and Group 3 (migrated with separation from mothers). Mothers differed significantly in level of education, with Group 1 mothers more highly educated, while children differed significantly in current age, age at migration, and length of time in the United States. Child problems were measured by the Jamaican Youth Checklist (Lambert, Knight, Taylor & Newell, 1993), a modification of the Achenbach Child Behavior Checklist (Achenbach & Edelbrock, 1978). Child self-esteem was measured by the Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventory (Coopersmith, 1981), verbal intelligence by the Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test - Revised (Dunn & Dunn, 1981) and life stress by the Life Events Scale - Children (Coddington, 1972). Mothers' psychological adjustment was measured by the Brief Symptom Inventory (Derogatis, 1975). Both used the Family Adaptability and Cohesion Scales-II to describe family functioning (Olson, Portner, & Lavee, 1985). In comparison with U.S. and Jamaican norms, the children studied had significantly higher levels of internalizing problems. For externalizing problems, these children scored higher than did children in Jamaica, but significantly lower than U.S. children. However, there were no significant differences among the three groups in this study on any outcome measures, such as stress level, self-esteem, verbal fluency, or child problems. Mult (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Prenatal substance abuse exposure: Effects on the maternal-infant interaction.
column10: Liguori, Rosemary: Oklahoma State U, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(9-B), Mar 1996, pp. 4816.
column18: Scope and method of study. This study investigated the effect of prenatal cocaine exposure on vocal, visual, tactile and mutual gaze interactions of neonates (ages 2-28 days) and their mothers. Two groups (exposed versus non exposed) of 30 infant-mother dyads were used. Prior to data analysis, the groups were examined for demographic differences. The neonates and their mothers were videotaped in their homes by the principal investigator. The Neonatal Perception Inventory (NPI) was completed by the mothers to examine this aspect of the two groups. Findings and conclusions. A convenience sample consisted of 17 female and 13 male neonates in the cocaine exposed group with a mean age of 20.5 days, and 12 females and 18 males in the non cocaine exposed group with a mean age of 18.5 days. There was a higher incidence of caucasians in the cocaine group mothers (70%), compared to 23% African American and 7% of mixed race. The non cocaine group, consisted of 40% of caucasian, 33% of African American and 27% of mixed race. The age range for both groups of women was between 16-40 years. There were no significant statistical differences in the vocal, visual, tactile, and mutual gaze interactive behaviors between the two groups, nor were significant statistical differences found for gender, or gender and group interaction. Both groups of mothers viewed their neonates positively, as measured by the NPI. Implications for a qualitative investigation of cocaine exposed dyad seems warranted, since differences were noted anecdotally. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Roommate satisfaction and ethnic pride were assessed in 101 same-race and mixed-race randomly assigned roommate pairs (aged 17-28 yrs) at the University of Georgia. There were 39 African American roommate pairs, 30 White pairs, and 32 African- American-White pairs. The Ss were interviewed by means of a telephone survey. Perceptions of the roommate relationships were measured using the Roomate Relationship Inventory and ethnic pride was assessed using The Ethnicity Questionnaire. African American roommate pairs indicated significantly greater roommate satisfaction than did African American-White pairs. African American roommate pairs also had the highest ethnic pride score. Implications for practice and further research directions are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The impact of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection on quality of life in a multiracial South African population.
column10: O'Keefe, A. E.: U Cape Town, Somerset Hosp, Dept of Medicine, Cape Town, South Africa
column11: Quality of Life Research: An International Journal of Quality of Life Aspects of Treatment, Care & Rehabilitation. Vol.5(2), Apr 1996, pp. 275-280.
column18: Used the Medical Outcomes Survey SF-36 instrument to determine if the quality of life (QOL) in males and females with HIV was affected by race, gender, or clinical stage of disease. Ss were 134 HIV outpatients (aged 20-40 yrs, 42 White, 49 Mixed race and 43 Black), who were referred to an HIV clinic in western Cape Town, South Africa, and 115 healthy, non-medical hospital personnel (36 Whites, 37 Mixed race, 42 Blacks). Scores on 8 QOL concepts were assessed. Black female controls scored significantly lower on all scales except physical function. HIV-infected Ss of Mixed race (both genders) reported poorer physical function; no other scale was affected by race. HIV Ss scored significantly lower on all scales; the majority of the decline in function occurred early in disease by WHO stages 1 and 2. It is concluded that HIV infection impacts early on all aspects of QOL and that this impact is largely independent of racial origin. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Examined the type and extent of, and reasons for bullying within and between 156 British Asian (A) and White (W) girls and boys. Ss (aged 8-10 yrs) were asked to nominate bullies (B) and victims (V) from their class or any other class in the school and about specific types of B. Race of preferred partners for shared activities and racial stereotypes were assessed. Results show no significant differences in number of A and W Ss nominated as either B or V. Both A and W Ss were significantly more likely to be named as B of other race classmates. In case of boys, there were no significant correlations between general racial preferences/attitudes on the one hand, and the extent to which they were named by classmates as B of other race children on the other hand. More A Ss than W Ss reported that they had been teased about their color or race, and the opposite was the case for the non-racial types of teasing. column10: Hirschfeld, Lawrence A.: U Michigan, Dept of Anthropology, Ann Arbor, US
column11: Child Development. Vol.66(5), Oct 1995, pp. 1418-1437.
column18: Examined beliefs about inheritability of identity and racial characteristics of mixed-race children. In Exp 1, 32 children (aged 7-21 yrs) and 43 undergraduates described the category membership of mixed-race children and the degree to which they resembled each parent. Exp 2 investigated whether 36 children (age 7-12 yrs) and 18 adults expected mixed-race children to have White, Black, or intermediate features. Exp 3 explored 46 children's (age 7-22) expectations about the inheritability of the same properties in animals. Older children, like adults, believed mixed-race children have Black racial features. Adults believe such children inherit the categorical identity of the minority parent. Exp 4 repeated these tasks with 39 Black and White children (age 7-22) attending an integrated school. Unlike children attending a predominantly White school, Ss in the integrated school expect mixed-race children to have intermediate racial features. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Describes the case of a 23-yr-old American Indian male with fetal alcohol syndrome, who was adopted at 4 mo of age by an upper middle class mixed race couple. The S had low birth weight, microcephaly, seizures, and defective bladder and kidneys. In school, S showed inappropriate friendliness to strangers, impulsivity, learning disabilities, and problems with organizational skills. Mental health deterioration of S occurred at 21 yrs of age and he had a serious psychotic breakdown. He was transferred from a state hospital to a community hospital and was on anticonvulsant and antipsychotic medications. He was later transferred to a regional community mental health facility for outpatient care. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column10: Zack, Naomi: State U New York, Albany, NY, US
column11: (1995). American mixed race: The culture of microdiversity. xxv, 379 pp. Lanham, MD, England: Rowman & Littlefield; England.
column18: (from the publicity materials) This . . . multidisciplinary collection brings together 22 original essays by scholars . . . of racial theory, who address both the American concept of race and the specific problems experienced by those who do not fit neatly into the boxes society requires them to check. Through identity theory, autobiography, art, social science, and public policy, the contributors to "American Mixed Race" explore this position of "microdiversity," or diversity within individuals. While they share a consensus that the biological concept of race is false, some contributors want to identify as mixed race while others opt for a reclaimed version of traditional racial and ethnic identities. Still others are skeptical of all identifications. "American Mixed Race" will be useful for undergraduate and graduate courses in multiculturalism, racial identity, American Studies, African-American Studies, Latino and Native American studies, Asian-American Studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial differences in adolescent self-report: A comparative validity study using homogeneous MMPI content measures. [References].
column10: Wrobel, Nancy Howells: U Michigan, Dept of Behavioral Sciences, Dearborn, US
column11: Psychological Assessment. Vol.7(2), Jun 1995, pp. 140-147.
column18: Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventories (MMPIs) were administered to an urban-mixed-race sample of adolescent psychiatric inpatients and outpatients (N = 218). Racial differences were noted on 4 of the 13 raw Wiggins scale scores, with scores for African-American patients more elevated on Poor Health, Feminine Interests, Phobias, and Psychoticism. A backward multiple-regression procedure was used to predict raw Wiggins scale scores from parent descriptions as measured by the Personality Inventory for Children clinical scales. Predictors supported the validity of the Organic Symptoms, Social Maladjustment, Family Problems, Authority Conflict, and Hypomania scales, and to some extent, Poor Morale, Depression, Poor Health, and Phobias. Predictors differed across racial groups for 9 of the scales, with particular discrepancies in predictive meaning for Poor Health, Hypomania, Family Problems, and Authority Conflict. Implications for MMPI-A content scales are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: American Sociological Review. Vol.59(3), Jun 1994, pp. 446-460.
column18: Explored the growth in reading comprehension (RDC) over the 1st 2 yrs of school among a mixed-race random sample of children in Baltimore, Maryland. Black Ss in integrated schools made less progress in RDC in winter than did their counterparts in segregated schools. In summers, however, when they were not in school, the Black Ss who attended integrated schools gained more than their counterparts who attended segregated schools. White Ss made about the same progress in RDC in integrated and segregated schools in winters and summers, even though the Whites in integrated schools came from more educationally advantaged families. Ss of both races in integrated schools, who came from more educated families, did not make the expected gains in RDC when school was open. In summers, however, Ss whose parents had more education forged ahead of those whose parents were high school dropouts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column10: Rotenberg, Ken J.: Lakehead U, Dept of Psychology, Thunder Bay, ON, Canada
column11: The Journal of Social Psychology. Vol.134(5), Oct 1994, pp. 621-631.
column18: Studied 65 Native American and 96 White children (mean age 10 yrs) attending 4th or 5th grade in same-race or mixed-race Canadian schools who judged themselves and the other group with respect to trust. As hypothesized, Ss displayed same-race trust expectancies: Native American Ss expected a White child to be less likely to keep promises, keep secrets, and tell the truth than a Native American child. The White Ss displayed the opposite pattern of expectancies. The same-race pattern of trust was less evident in mixed-race schools than in same-race schools but, consistent with the behavioral disconfirmation hypothesis, only for expectancies of promise keeping. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column10: Lochman, John E.: Duke U Medical Ctr, Dept of Psychiatry, Durham, NC, US
column11: Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry. Vol.33(7), Sep 1994, pp. 1026-1035.
column18: Examined a mixed-race sample of 114 boys (mean age 11 yrs at 1st assessment) 2 times, 4 yrs apart, to assess the relative power of aggression, low peer acceptance, and race in predicting a broad range of adolescent outcomes and behaviors. Outcomes were assessed through self-report and through peer, teacher, and independent observer ratings. Preadolescent levels of aggression were predictive of Ss' subsequent adolescent involvement in marijuana, drugs, alcohol, and delinquent activity. Aggression and low peer acceptance served as predictors of teacher, peer, and independent observer ratings of externalizing and internalizing behavior at follow-up. Race was a moderating variable in the longitudinal effects of low peer acceptance and aggression for certain types of outcomes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: (from the jacket) [This book] comprehensively addresses mental health issues relevant to women of color and presents guidelines for state-of-the-art treatment. Chapters illustrate the interaction of gender and ethnicity in mental health theory and practice, and discuss how cultural relevance and gender sensitivity can and must be incorporated into clinical work. . . . Inclusive in its approach and rich with illustrative case examples, [this book] covers issues that affect both familiar and frequently overlooked groups of women. Filling a significant gap in the literature, [this book] is a major new resource for all mental health professionals, from students to seasoned practitioners. Accessibly written, it also serves as an excellent classroom text for courses in the psychology of women, women's studies, and gender studies. column5: Breaking bad news to parents with disabled children: A cross-cultural study.
column10: Krauss-Mars, A. H.: Children's Ctr, Rondebosch, South Africa
column11: Child: Care, Health and Development. Vol.20(2), Mar-Apr 1994, pp. 101-113.
column18: Investigated the problems parents experienced when told that their child was physically and/or mentally disabled across different ethnic groups in South Africa. The parents of 65 children (aged 2-85 mo) drawn from a sample of 40 mixed race, 26 White, and 24 Black children participated. Except for the Xhosa speaking parents, the majority of parents received the diagnosis in their own language (English or Afrikaans). Most Xhosa speaking parents denied having received an explanation of the diagnosis, or having had an opportunity to ask questions. Only a few Black parents reported being asked as to their understanding of the diagnosis. White parents tended to deny the diagnosis of mental handicap more often than the other groups despite reporting that explanations were given. Most parents felt satisfied with the way the news was given to them and reported good progress in their children, and some of them expected their children to go to a normal school. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Surveying the intersection: Pathology, secrecy, and the discourses of racial and sexual identity.
column10: Diggs, Marylynne: U Oregon, Eugene, US
column11: Journal of Homosexuality. Vol.26(2-3), 1993, pp. 1-19.
column18: Cautions against the risks of metaphorical imperialism in readings of codified gay and lesbian representation. The author disagrees with M. Foucault's (1978) view that the secret of the 19th century was the secret of sex, and suggests that, in 19th-century American culture, where African-American identity and equality were among the most controversial issues, the secrets of identity were also secrets of race. Because scientific and literary representations of pathological and/or secret essential identities are sites of intersection in the discourses of homosexual and mixed-race identity, they should be investigated as intersections, rather than read as codifications of sexual difference. A survey of the discourses of scientific racism, genetics, and eugenics suggests that F. E. Harper's (1892 [1987]) representation of the mulatto leader can be read as an act of resistance to the representation of the mulatto as a degenerate, hybrid species. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Tested the consequences of ignoring or overriding the distinctive features of the cognitive system by which Brazilians express their race/color identities. A salient vernacular term (morena) was substituted for the seldom-used term (parda) that the Brazilian census offers as self-identification for a person who has both Black and White color/race features. When morena was offered in a split census, the proportion of respondents who self-identified as being of mixed color/race substantially increased while the proportion identifying as White or Black substantially declined. Findings suggest an error of imposing on the rest of the hemisphere rigid dichotomous (White/non-White) or trichotomous (White/mixed/Black) categories deemed appropriate for establishing racial identity in the US. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: (from the chapter) in free play situations, such as the playground, research suggests that children do not select their partners on a random basis / rather they appear to actively seek out the company of peers or avoid them on the basis of certain characteristics / present details and data that relate to this issue, with particular reference to race and sex / our data come from a longitudinal project on aspects of peer relations in three ethnically mixed middle schools in the UK / examine preferences shown by subgroups of children [aged 8-10 years] for engaging in certain types of activities on the playground, as well as the relationship between children's stated and observed preferences aims of our investigation were: 1. to compare observed own-sex and own-race preferences, in the playground of British boys and girls, of both white and Asian origin / 2. to investigate observed race and sex differences in preferred group size, and categories of playground behavior / 3. to relate observed partner preferences to stated partner preferences (obtained from interview) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: (from the introduction) The purpose of this volume is to provide a collection of research and review papers that shed light on practical and empirical child developmental issues in the context of outdoor play environments. Although there has been a long history of studying children in many different settings (e.g., the home, the classroom), the playground is just beginning to be viewed as an important context for development that warrants further investigation. . . . Such environments allow researchers and practitioners the opportunity to explore child behavior and development as it naturally evolves in the context of minimal adult supervision. This volume should be of particular interest to both researchers and practitioners who work with preschool and school-age children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Reports the findings of a British, 12-yr follow-up study (C. Bagley et al, 1979) of 27 Afro-Caribbean and mixed-race children (mean age 19 yrs) adopted by Caucasian parents, and 25 Caucasian children (mean age 19.2 yrs) adopted by same-race parents. Ss completed questionnaires, including the Crown-Crisp Experiential Index, Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventories, and a measure of identity. Outcomes for both groups of adoptees in terms of adjustment and identity were generally excellent, although 10% of both groups had poor adjustment. There was no evidence from this or other studies that intercultural identity leads to unfavorable adjustment. Ss seemed well prepared by transracial adoption to participate effectively in a multicultural, multiracial society. Transracial adoptions should be considered for all children who cannot be placed inracially. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Examined contextual factors affecting the way in which Latinos living in the US respond to questions of race. In the 1980 Census, 40% of Hispanics identified themselves racially as "other." In 1990 this proportion increased. In the current study, a nonrandom sample of 58 Latinos responded that they were "other" to a replica of the 1980 Census question on race. Results counter the interpretation that those who identify as "other" are of mixed race (mestizo) or misunderstand the question. Rather, the "other" response, it is argued, reflects a widespread view among Latinos that race is not so much a biological as a cultural, social, and/or political concept. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: (1992). Racially mixed people in America. viii, 387 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column18: (from the cover) America has been the breeding ground of a "biracial baby boom" for the past 25 years. Unfortunately, there has been a dearth of information regarding how racially mixed people identify and view themselves and how they relate to one another. "Racially Mixed People in America" steadily bridges this gap, and offers a comprehensive look at the social and psychological adjustment of multiracial people, models for identity development, contemporary immigration and marriage patterns, and methodological issues involved in conducting research with mixed-race people, all in the context of America's multiracial past and present. Including contributions by ethnohistorians, psychologists, and sociologists, this powerful volume will provide the reader a tool for examining ideologies surrounding race, race relations, and the role of social science in the deconstruction of race. "Racially Mixed People in America" is essential reading for researchers and practitioners in cross-cultural studies, psychology, family studies, sociology, and social work. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Journal of Applied Psychology. Vol.77(3), Jun 1992, pp. 363-371.
column18: Examined the effects of interviewer and interviewee race and age similarity on interview outcomes under 2 different interview formats: a conventional structured panel interview and a situational panel interview. A total of 2,805 applicants were interviewed. The panels consisted of same-, mixed-, or different-race and same-, mixed-, or different-age groups. Analyses revealed stronger same-race effects with the conventional structured interview than with the situational interview. Furthermore, these same-race effects could be avoided by using mixed-race interview panels. No age similarity effects were detected with either interview procedure. Implications for future research and practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Annual Progress in Child Psychiatry & Child Development.  1991, pp. 619-639.
column18: (This reprinted article originally appeared in the Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry and Allied Disciplines, 1990, 31[4], 493-510. The following abstract of the original article appeared in PA, Vol 77:29209.) Adoption is now seen as a form of child care, one of a spectrum of resources for children in need. Adopted children generally show a good outcome but are overrepresented in clinical populations. This trend is likely to continue as older children with histories of severe deprivation, neglect, abuse, and institutionalization are placed. Attitudes toward the adoption of mixed-race and older children are also changing: Black and mixed-race children are becoming easier to place. Developmental studies have thrown new light on revealing to children that they were adopted. Adoption disruption increases with age and other factors at placement, requiring further research into its origins and management. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Induced happy, neutral, or sad moods in 198 students and then investigated mood effects on Ss' perceptions of Asian (heterostereotype) or Caucasian (autostereotype) characters who were part of a same-race or a mixed-race dyad. As predicted, consistent mood-congruent biases were found. However, both positive and negative mood effects were significantly greater when a target was part of a mixed-race dyad, a condition presumably requiring more detailed and substantive inferential processing. Findings are interpreted in terms of current affect-cognition theories. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Developmental Psychology. Vol.23(5), Sep 1987, pp. 676-682.
column18: This study looked for long-term effects of Cesarean birth, using a stratified mixed-race random sample of Baltimore school children who began first grade in 1982. There were no effects on children's California Achievement Test scores in the verbal or math domains at the start of Grade 1. There were also no effects on a personal maturity/temperament measure or on special problem status in Grade 1. Parents of Cesarean-born children, nevertheless, believed that their children had more ability to do schoolwork than did parents of other children, and the Cesarean-born children themselves expected higher marks in reading and math than did other children. These findings dove-tail with the limited prior research on short-term or long-term sociopsychological effects of Cesarean birth on children or on parents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Tested an unobtrusive measure of prejudice and 2 competing theories of prejudice-sexual threat and incentive conflict-using 2 experiments with a total of 72 White men (aged approximately 30 yrs). The impact of social processes on Ss' reactions to intimacy in interracial couples was measured as Ss observed heterosexual couples of same or mixed race moving through a shopping center. Results show that sexual threat did affect responses to interracial couples but that those responses were also affected by the value support that interracial couples provided for White norms, as predicted by incentive conflict. Ss were 22 12-17 yr olds of mixed race and religious affiliation. Choral music led to related group activities; other results of the project during 21/2 yrs are also described. column18: Examined the factor structure of the NSAGT on the basis of data from 4 groups of 13-yr-olds-319 White Afrikaans-speaking, 171 White English-speaking, 498 Indian English-speaking, and 469 mixed-race Afrikaans-speaking children-to find a single factor model that is optimal in accuracy and simplicity. Although great similarities were found between the factor structures of the 4 populations, the factor structures were not invariant. Factorial invariance was shown to exist for the 2 high socioeconomic status (SES) groups and for the 2 low SES groups. A marked similarity between the nonverbal reasoning factors was also found for all populations. (34 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race and inequity.
column10: Gray-Little, Bernadette: U North Carolina, Chapel Hill
column11: Journal of Applied Social Psychology. Vol.10(6), Nov-Dec 1980, pp. 468-481.
column18: Examined, in 2 experiments, the effects of beneficiary-victim status and race on the reactions of 173 4th and 5th graders to an inequitable allocation. In Exp I, mixed-race dyads of Black or White Ss were subjected to profitable or unprofitable inequity by Black or White allocators. Ss were then allowed to request portions of a 2nd reward and were interviewed to assess inequity distress and their cognitive reactions to the experience of being a beneficiary or victim. Allocator's race was found to have a significant impact on the efforts of Black victims to redistribute rewards and to be relevant to all Ss' perceptions of the inequity. Ss' race and beneficiary-victim status influenced their interpretations of the initial allocation and the amount of distress experienced. Exp II examined the impact of race of observer and participant on observers' perceptions of an inequitable allocation. Overall results confirm the pervasive and complex impact of racial identity on reactions to inequity, pointing to its influence even on persons who have nothing tangible to gain or lose by their ratings and allocations. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Tested the hypothesis that writing picture-interpretation stories in a 2nd language makes Ss more stimulus-bound and therefore more likely to fragment in time the events occurring in the picture (polyphasic perception). 144 Rhodesian upper primary-school children responded to the same pictures in either English or Shona. No relationship between language medium and stimulus-binding or between stimulus-binding and polyphasic responding was observed. Furthermore, a previously observed preponderance of polyphasic responses by African children failed to appear, and a 2nd sample of 59 "Colored" and "Asian" (Indian) children gave fewer polyphasic responses than Western children normally do. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Examined the hypothesis that psychosocial resources (including social supports and coping styles) help to protect individuals from risk associated with psychosocial stressors and that the protective effect may extend to standard risk factors as well. In a study of 128 Ss (mean age 33.1 yrs) conducted in Brazil, it was found that psychosocial resources modified Black-White differences in blood pressure. Highest mean blood pressures were observed among mixed-race and Black Brazilians who had low psychosocial resources; Afro-Brazilians with high psychosocial resources had lower blood pressures than White Brazilians. Implications of these results for the mechanisms linking ethnicity, psychosocial factors, and blood pressure are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Freeman, Edith M

column11: Social Work in Education. Vol.8(3), Spr 1986, pp. 164-174.
column18: Presents an assessment and intervention program designed to serve mixed-race children who experience racial identity problems, with emphasis on the linkage among the school, home, and community. A case example of a 7-yr-old boy with a White mother and a Black father shows the role of school social workers in assessing problems and assisting these children to develop positive racial self-concepts and successful school adjustment. Two basic processes involved in the development of racial identity are discussed-racial conception and racial evaluation. To promote prevention, school social workers should develop ways to identify students who are at-risk for racial-identity problems even before those problems may be manifested, and develop skills for assessing and intervening in family and organizational dynamics related to racial-identity issues. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Relationships between ethnicity, conceptions of mental illness, and attitudes associated with seeking psychological help.
column9:
Hall, Lena E

Tucker, Carolyn M
column10: Hall, Lena E.: Kenyon Coll, Health & Counseling Ctr
column11: Psychological Reports. Vol.57(3, Pt 1), Dec 1985, pp. 907-916.
column18: Examined the relationships between ethnicity, conceptions of mental illness, and attitudes associated with seeking psychological help in 321 White and 192 Black schoolteachers (aged 20+ yrs). Ss completed a conception of mental illness questionnaire, an attitude scale, vignettes that elicited opinions on certain counseling issues, and a demographic datasheet. Results indicate significant differences between Blacks and Whites in their conceptions of mental illness; Blacks' responses were more stereotypic, and Whites' were closer to those of mental health professionals. Both Blacks and Whites had similar positive attitudes toward seeking psychological help; however, significantly more Whites had actually been in therapy. Blacks showed more positive attitudes toward mixed-race dyads in counseling but showed more negative attitudes concerning the efficacy of psychological treatment for certain problems. Conception of mental illness was significantly related to attitudes associated with seeking psychological help. Findings support the assertions of C. Tucker (1979) that the different conceptualization of mental illness among Blacks may be a factor in their underutilization of mental health services. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1984, Vol 29(3), 247-248. Reviews the book, Threatened Identities edited by Glynis M. Breakwell (1983). The volume comprises eleven chapters that, after an introductory chapter by the editor, are loosely grouped into three sections, threats to individual identity (e.g., prompted by the breakdown of personal relationships), threats to the individual as group member (e.g., the marginal identities of members of some mixed-race groups), and threats to the identity of groups themselves (e.g., threats to the identity of a community from environmental change). For many American readers the book will seem especially parochial, just as many books published in America are similarly regarded by readers elsewhere. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: "Mixed race" children in British society: Some theoretical considerations.
column11: British Journal of Sociology. Vol.35(1), Mar 1984, pp. 42-61.
column18: Contends that the study of racial identity of mixed-race children in the UK raises a number of theoretical issues about the racial categorization system of Britain-in particular, the validity of the assumption that British racial thought is strictly dichotomous (perceived in terms of 2 mutually exclusive categories). In sociological literature of the UK and US, mixed-race people have often been described as occupying a marginal or in-between position from which they can only escape by adopting full membership in 1 group or the other. However, some sociologists suggest that it is possible for mixed-race people to steer a successful course between the 2 groups or to alter their racial self-image according to circumstance; ethnic identity is considered to be more fluid and dynamic than is frequently depicted. It is suggested that the dichotomous Black or White model of racial identity stems from analysis of the US racial structure, but investigation of racial identity in the UK requires a more flexible view of the racial categorization system. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The identity of transracial adoptees.

McRoy, Ruth G

Zurcher, Louis A

Lauderdale, Michael L

Anderson, Rosalie E
column10: McRoy, Ruth G.: U Texas Ctr for Social Work Research, School of Social Work, Austin
column11: Social Casework. Vol.65(1), Jan 1984, pp. 34-39.
column18: Examined familial and contextual factors that influenced the development of racial self-perceptions among 30 Black or mixed-race children and adolescents (aged 10-21 yrs) who had been adopted by White parents. Questionnaires and interviews with both children and parents revealed 3 ways that families dealt with racial identity issues. 18 of the families rarely discussed racial issues or associated with Blacks, and the children perceived themselves as different from other Blacks in terms of attitudes and culture. These children also held strong feelings of "differentness" and negative attitudes toward other Blacks. A 2nd group of 6 families acknowledged the child's racial identity and the need to provide Black role models for the child. These families lived in integrated neighborhoods, and the children expressed an interest in contact with other Blacks and often discussed racial identity issues with parents and peers. A 3rd group, in which parents generally had adopted several Black children, were characterized as interracial, and children were taught to emphasize their Black heritage. These families also provided a psychological support network for the adopted children. Findings suggest that transracial adoptions require special efforts on the part of parents and children and postplacement work on the part of the adoption agency. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Women in interracial relationships.
column10: Faulkner, Janette: U California, Langley Porter Neuropsychiatric Inst, San Francisco
column11: Women & Therapy. Vol.2(2-3), Sum-Fal 1983, pp. 191-203.
column18: Describes the activities, experiences, and concerns of members of 7 support groups that helped participants work on issues related to different- or mixed-race living during a 3-yr period. 25 White, 12 Black, and 1 Chinese Ss lived with partners and/or children of a different or mixed race. Initial group encounters were intellectual and somewhat educational as Ss shared their life experiences. Armoring was used by Black and other Ss of color to promote self-caring during direct encounters with racist experiences. Co-leaders of the group were a Black clinician (the author) paired with a graduate student who had or was experiencing a mixed race relationship. Most Ss moved to the host environment of the spouse upon marriage. Group activity focused on establishing a definite identity for children and reinforcing it with models to support pridefulness. Group concerns about childrearing practices were racial: White Ss were criticized for being too permissive with children, and Black Ss were criticized by spouses for being too strict and by their families for being too permissive. Ss needed support and clarification around the question of what is developmental and what is cultural. Ss were trained to take leadership roles and continued meeting in their homes. A 5-item bibliography is appended. (1 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Conducted 3 convergent studies to investigate the hypothesis that task-irrelevant status attributes of peers influence judgment of deservingness more for younger than for older children. In Study 1, 112 Black and White 1st and 3rd graders allocated rewards to peer pairs whose members were either both Black or both White. Allocations of 1st graders were more influenced by the player's race than were the 3rd graders'. In Study 2, 144 Black and White 1st and 3rd graders made allocations to pairs in which one partner was Black and the other White. Relative size and task performance were also varied. Player's race did not influence allocations, but relative size did. In Study 3, 68 Ss who had been 1st-grade Ss in Studies 1 or 2 were reassessed 4 yrs later. Also, 77 new 5th graders served as Ss. Allocations of younger Ss and of Ss who had been held back in elementary school were less task-based than those of older and promoted Ss. Results are discussed in terms of children's cognitive capacities, equity theory, status generalization, and the development of fair-play standards. (38 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: Observed the tendency of shoppers at a suburban shopping mall to walk between conversing Black, White, or mixed-race male dyads. Both male and female shoppers (N = 508, 93.7% White) were more likely to walk through the Black dyad than through the White or the mixed-race dyads. Results are interpreted as indicating a relative lack of consideration for the Black dyad's interaction territory. When walking around a mixed-race dyad, shoppers more often chose to pass behind the White member. Findings suggest that the often subtle effects of racial attitudes can be studied unobtrusively using the invasion of shared space paradigm. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column18: 42 same-sex pairs of varied racial composition were randomly selected from 8th graders in each of 2 matched schools, with open- vs closed-space architectural styles. Open-space Ss were more likely to develop cooperative interdependence in a mixed-motive game (a decomposed prisoner's dilemma) and were more inclined to make proximal seating choices indicative of anticipated peer interaction. A Sex by Race by Trial Blocks interaction effect reflected different patterns of responding for males and females. Females of either race learned to cooperate in same-race pairs and to compete in mixed-race pairs. White males learned to cooperate and Black males to compete independent of their partner's race. External scores on Rotter's Internal-External Locus of Control Scale were not related to schools but were, as expected, higher for Black than for White students. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Categorical and contextual bases of person memory and stereotyping. [References].
column9:
Taylor, Shelley E

Fiske, Susan T

Etcoff, Nancy L

Ruderman, Audrey J
column10: Taylor, Shelley E.: Harvard U
column11: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.36(7), Jul 1978, pp. 778-793.
column18: In 3 studies, a total of 207 White university summer school students observed slide and type portrayals of interacting small groups that were of mixed sex or mixed race. Hypotheses were that (a) social perceivers encode person information by race and sex; (b) this fact leads to minimizing within-group and exaggerating between-group differences; (c) perceivers stereotype accordingly; (d) within-group attributes, both stereotyped and nonstereotyped, are exaggerated in inverse proportion to the size of the minority subgroup; (e) better discriminations are made within smaller subgroups; (f) imputations of attributes to groups as a whole are also sensitive to the makeup of the group; and (g) all these behaviors are attenuated when the perceiver is a member of the subgroup evaluated. All but the last hypothesis received at least partial support. Results are discussed in terms of categorization processes and suggest that normal cognitive processes explain the process of stereotyping quite well. (32 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effects of race on observer judgments of nonverbal communications.
column9:
Forgas, Joseph P

Brown, L. B
column10: Forgas, Joseph P.: U New South Wales, School of Psychology, Kensington, Australia
column11: The Journal of Social Psychology. Vol.104(2), Apr 1978, pp. 243-251.
column18: Studied the effects of race on observer judgments of nonverbal communications (NVC) with the use of 2 sets of stimulus slides, showing (a) White or Black males individually and (b) same race (White) or mixed race (Black male, White female) interacting couples. For both sets of stimuli, 2 levels of nonverbal behavior were programmed, a "neutral" stance and a "positive," or in the case of couples, an "intimate" stance. The stimuli were presented to a 60-student sample and judgments were recorded on a set of 6 bipolar scales. Multivariate ANOVAs indicated that while NVC effects were highly significant for both sets of stimuli, race effects were only significant on evaluative scales, and this effect could be wholly attributed to an interaction of race and NVC cues. Thus, for individual stimulus persons, the effects of positive NVC are relatively attenuated for Black models, and for couples the effects of nonverbal intimacy are more accentuated for mixed-race couples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

The special problems of mixed-race children adopted by White couples and the difficulties of children in long-term foster homes were also examined. column5: Children's ability to recognize other children's faces.
column10: Feinman, Saul: U Wyoming
column11: Child Development. Vol.47(2), Jun 1976, pp. 506-510.
column18: Studied facial recognition ability in 288 children from 4 grades-1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 6th-who also varied by sex, race, and school type, the last being segregated or integrated. Ss judged whether each of 40 pictures of children's faces had been present in a set of 20 pictures viewed earlier. Facial recognition ability increased significantly with each grade but leveled off between ages 8 and 11. Blacks' performance was significantly better than Whites', and Blacks were better at recognizing faces of Whites than Whites were at recognizing Blacks. Ss from an integrated school showed smaller differences recognizing Black or White faces than Ss from segregated schools, but the effect appeared only for Ss of the integrated school who also lived in mixed-race neighborhoods. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of racial composition and group size on interactional patterns in preschool children.
column9:
Harrison, Murelle G

Messe, Lawrence A

Stollak, Gary E
column10: Harrison, Murelle G.: Michigan State U
column11: Proceedings of the Annual Convention of the American Psychological Association. Vol.6(Pt. 1), 1971, pp. 325-326.
column18: Previous research has indicated that preschool-aged children are aware of racial differences, but this awareness does not affect their interaction in mixed-race groups. The present study extended this work by comparing 2- and 4-person homogeneous and racially mixed groups of 31/2-5 yr. old children. Results indicate that the frequencies of initiations and negative responses were lower in 4-person racially mixed groups than in 4-person homogeneous groups. Also, the ratio of responses in general to initiations was lower in mixed groups than in homogeneous groups. Thus, racial awareness was found to inhibit social behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Language and non-verbal test performance of racial groups in Honolulu before and after a fourteen-year interval.
column11: Journal of General Psychology. Vol.26 1942, pp. 51-93.
column18: Public school children in Honolulu between the ages of 10 and 15 were tested with special tests: non-verbal and comprehension of spoken and printed English (forms and directions are given in appendices). The scores of the racial groups and the total population in general were superior in 1938 to what they were in 1924, but the rank order of the racial groups changed only slightly over the interval; the high-scoring groups made more improvement than the low-scoring groups. More improvement was made in the non-verbal test than in the English tests. 1924 group non-verbal scores predicted 1938 group printed English comprehension scores better than 1938 group non-verbal scores. No downward trend in non-verbal scores with increasing age was shown for low as compared with high scoring groups. There was a high correspondence between school achievement rank and rank order in test scores. "The mixed races fall midway between parent stocks in non-verbal test score, and approach the higher scoring parent stock in verbal tests and in school achievement. The mixed race variability is below expectation." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column19: HAWAII, RACE, INTELLIGENCE, RACE, INTELLIGENCE, HAWAII, INTELLIGENCE, RACE, HAWAII, ENGLISH, COMPREHENSION, RACE, HAWAII, EDUCATIONAL PSYCHOLOGY (INCL. VOCATIONAL GUIDANCE)

column5: On the variability of mixed races.
column11: American Naturalist. Vol.70 1936, pp. 409-442.
column13: The University of Chicago Press; US
column18: Principles of Mendelian genetics are not violated by anthropological findings that mixed races formed by hybridization between major known races have on the whole little or no more variability, perhaps in some cases even less, than the original races. However, "unincreased variability can not (as sometimes stated) be related to the number of generations of breeding of the mixed race, but must be as evident in F2 as later." Several possible Mendelian interpretations are given: (1) the more plausible is that most of "the intraracial variation of the original races is caused by relatively recessive genes that individually (at each given locus) are rather rare, but taken together are numerous"; and (2) "this variation is for the most part referable to different loci in the different major races, even though a variation of a similar phenotypic kind results." Requirements are stated that should be met by any future body of data dealing with the problem at issue. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column19: VARIABILITY, RACE MIXTURES, RACE, MIXTURE, VARIABILITY AND, GENERAL SOCIAL PROCESSES (INCL. ESTHETICS)

column5: Social significance of Huntington's chorea.
column11: The American Journal of Psychiatry. Vol.4 1925, pp. 537-574.
column18: A study of 218 cases shows the following: (1) The disease is not frequent in the Michigan state hospitals. (2) It appears to be one of the few strictly inheritable diseases. (3) The age of onset varies widely. (4) There seems to be no reliable indication in early life of the later development of the disease. (5) Behavior difficulties appeared in two-thirds of the choreics. (6) With regard to mental disease, the greater number of the hospitalized cases were classified with the psychosis undifferentiated. (7) The average length of life after the development of the disease was found to be 16.1 years. (8) Exhaustion was the most frequent cause of death. (9) Seventeen cases of Sydenham's chorea were found to have occurred in otherwise non-choreic relatives; Sydenham's chorea also occurred in three individuals who afterward developed Huntington's chorea. (10) Other neuropathic conditions found in the families of choreics appear to be incidental. (11) The families were largely of mixed race and rural environment predominated. (12) Only 31 per cent of the choreics became public charges. (13) Potential choreics evidently do not abstain from marriage. Prevention will best be gained through education of the public to the dangers of transmission, in the hope that the affected stock will avoid marriage, or employ voluntary sterilization. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
